{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox football match | title = 2010 Leinster Football Final | image = | event = [[Leinster Senior Football Championship]] | team1 = [[Louth GAA|Louth]] | team1association = [[File:Cork colours.PNG|40px]] | team1score = 1–10 | team2 = [[Meath GAA|Meath]] | team2association = [[File:Donegal colours.jpg|40px]] | team2score = 1–12 | details = | date = 11 July 2010 | stadium = [[Croke Park]] | city = [[Dublin]] | man_of_the_match1a = | referee = [[Martin Sludden]] ([[Tyrone GAA|Tyrone]]) | attendance = 48,875 | weather = | previous = [[2009 Leinster Senior Football Championship Final|2009]] | next = [[2011 Leinster Senior Football Championship Final|2011]] }} The '''2010 Leinster Senior Football Championship Final''' was the last [[Gaelic football|football]] match of the 2010 [[Leinster Senior Football Championship]], played between [[Louth GAA|Louth]] and [[Meath GAA|Meath]] on 11 July 2010 in [[Croke Park]], Dublin.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0707/1224274220413.html|title=GAA – weekly fixtures|date=7 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=7 July 2010}} Louth were appearing in their first Leinster Senior Football Championship Final in 50 years. The game is memorable for its controversial ending. Meath won by 1–12 to 1–10, thanks to a controversial late goal by [[Joe Sheridan (Gaelic footballer)|Joe Sheridan]]. The goal was deemed illegal by television replays but was declared valid by referee Martin Sludden, from [[County Tyrone]].{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/northern_ireland/gaelic_games/8808677.stm|title=Referee Martin Sludden struck after Leinster decider|date=11 July 2010|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=11 July 2010}} He then blew the final whistle. Irate Louth fans stormed the [[Association football pitch|pitch]] and commenced a process of chasing and physically assaulting the referee, who had to be led away by a [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] escort in scenes broadcast to a live television audience. Other scenes of violence saw bottles being hurled from a stand, one striking a steward who fell to the ground. The situation led to much media debate in the week that followed, the violence was condemned by senior politicians (some of whom were in the stadium), and there were calls for the game to be replayed—though, ultimately, this did not happen. Seán Moran of ''[[The Irish Times]]'' said the next day: "What will be most vividly remembered of the 2010 final was compressed into a minute at the very end of the match with Louth getting ready to celebrate a deserved win – first over their neighbours in 35 years – and a resilient display".{{cite news|author=Moran, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0712/1224274518802.html|title=Controversy abounds as Meath claim title in hectic final minutes|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010}} Colm Keys of the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' said it was "hard to disagree" that it was "the greatest injustice for many a year in Croke Park",{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/sheridans-cruel-twist-denies-louth-2254831.html|title=Sheridan's cruel twist denies Louth|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} and remarked: "The 320th anniversary of the [[Battle of the Boyne]] is being commemorated today, but that surely didn't throw up a talking point to match a Joe Sheridan goal that will have the counties divided by [[River Boyne|the same river]] at odds for years to come".{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/fitzpatrick-slams-disgraceful-decision-2254830.html|title=Fitzpatrick slams 'disgraceful decision'|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} ==History of rivalry== Louth and Meath were rivals of old, both winning the [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]] in the 1950s; however, this was to be Louth's first appearance in the Leinster Senior Football Championship Final since a 1960 to [[Offaly GAA|Offaly]].{{cite news|author=Moran, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0710/1224274420582.html|title=Meath will look to win midfield battle|date=10 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=10 July 2010}} According to [[Colm O'Rourke]], "there was a time in the late 1940s and '50s when Meath and Louth were the two best teams in the province [of Leinster] and played some memorable championship games".{{cite news|author=O'Rourke, Colm|author-link=Colm O'Rourke|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/columnists/colm-orourke/colm-orourke-great-rivals-of-the-dim-and-distant-past-are-reunitedbut-louths-fairytale-day-wont-have-a-happy-ending-2254156.html|title=Great rivals of the dim and distant past are reunitedbut Louth's fairytale day won't have a happy ending|date=11 July 2010|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=11 July 2010}} Keith Duggan of ''The Irish Times'' reported that the two teams "fight like alley cats".{{cite news|author=Duggan, Keith|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0710/1224274420598.html|title=Border dispute with wee bit of history|date=10 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=10 July 2010}} They had last met four years previously in a preliminary round of the Leinster Senior Football Championship, with Meath emerging victorious. Louth had last defeated Meath in 1975, also at Croke Park. Three matches were required to produce a winner when the two encountered each other in July 1949. Other meetings include a draw in a semi-final of the 1951 Leinster Senior Football Championship, with Meath narrowly winning the replay. Meath also defeated Louth in the 1952 Leinster Senior Football Championship Final. Following on from Louth's aforementioned 1975 victory, there were other Meath wins in 1998, 2002 and 2006. ==Route to the final== '''Preliminary Round:''' Louth 1–11 [[Longford GAA|Longford]] 1–7; Meath 1–20 Offaly 2–7
'''Quarter-finals:''' Louth 1–22 [[Kildare GAA|Kildare]] 1–16; Meath 2–14 [[Laois GAA|Laois]] 0–10
'''Semi-finals:''' Louth 1–15 [[Westmeath GAA|Westmeath]] 2–10; Meath 5–9 [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] 0–13 ==Pre-match== ===Team selection=== On 9 July, both teams announced their teams for the final.{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0709/1224274348043.html|title=Kenny resumes his position in central role|date=9 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=9 July 2010|quote=Both Meath and Louth will today release their starting line-ups for Sunday's Leinster football final in Croke Park – and while Louth are likely to be unchanged from their semi-final win over Westmeath, Meath are expected to start Nigel Crawford at midfield, the only likely switch from the team which ripped Dublin apart in their semi-final.}} Meath announced their team first, with captain [[Nigel Crawford]], returning after injury, replacing [[Mark Ward (Meath GAA footballer born 1985)|Mark Ward]] in midfield.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0709/1224274378545.html|title=Crawford to start against Louth|date=9 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=9 July 2010|quote=Nigel Crawford comes into the Meath midfield for Sunday's Leinster final against Louth. Crawford, who has fully recovered from a back injury, will start alongside Brian Meade in the Meath engine room with Mark Ward making way. Louth manager Peter Fitzpatrick will announce his team later today.}} ===Attendance=== It was anticipated beforehand that attendance would be at its lowest of the decade, estimated at 45,000 or 50,000 by Ian O'Riordan of ''The Irish Times''.{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0709/1224274348000.html|title=Lowest crowd in decade due for final|date=9 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=9 July 2010}} 48,875 people attended the game. The issue of applying fencing around Croke Park to prevent pitch invasions had been discussed prior to the game.{{cite news|author=Moran, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0706/1224274102516.html|title=McKenna reiterates warning on fencing|date=6 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=6 July 2010|quote=Last Sunday, saw Kilkenny retain their provincial title against Galway without problems but a county winning a sixth successive provincial title is unlike to spark the same reaction as next weekend when Meath, for the first time in nine years, or Louth, for the first time in 50, will raise the Leinster football trophy.}} The violent scenes which followed the 2010 Leinster Senior Football Championship Final renewed this debate in the days afterwards,{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0713/1224274590265.html|title=GAA say fencing would be last resort|date=13 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=13 July 2010}} though President Cooney later said "the last thing we want to do is put fencing up around Croke Park".{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0720/cooneyc.html |title=Cooney confirms pitch presentations |date=20 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=20 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722063726/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0720/cooneyc.html |archivedate=22 July 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0720/1224275100231.html|title=GAA plans for on-pitch presentations|date=20 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=20 July 2010}} ==Match== ===Summary=== Louth's [[JP Rooney]] and [[Shane Lennon]] both missed opportunities in the first half.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0711/1224274490689.html|title=Rough justice for heartbroken Louth|date=11 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=11 July 2010}} Louth dominated the second half, though spurned numerous opportunities to take a commanding lead over Meath. Rooney scored a goal with seven minutes of the game left. Meath converted two long-range free kicks from [[Cian Ward]], but Louth still led by one point in the final minute. Louth's [[Colm Judge]] was sent off in the 69th minute for a second bookable offence. Then came the controversial goal by [[Joe Sheridan (Gaelic footballer)|Joe Sheridan]] in the third minute of stoppage time. The ball was kicked into the square by Graham Reilly. It came out to [[Seamus Kenny (footballer)|Seamus Kenny]], who could have gone for the point, but saw a goal chance and shot. But the ball was blocked by Louth captain [[Paddy Keenan]], and fell into the square, towards Louth full-back [[Dessie Finnegan]]. But Finnegan failed to clear and the ball went straight to Joe Sheridan, who fell over the goal line and then threw the ball into the net – both illegal moves. Sheridan was also "inside the square" at the time the ball reached him, in a third illegal move. Yet the goal was allowed and all of a sudden Meath were winning by two points. Referee Sludden checked with the umpire and did not change his mind, blowing his whistle for full-time soon after with the score at Meath 1–12: Louth 1–10, much to the disappointment of everyone associated with Louth. TV replays immediately demonstrated that the referee was incorrect when he awarded the goal to Meath. ===Violence=== Louth fans poured onto the pitch to express their feelings to the referee, and, in the words of ''The Irish Times'', "all hell broke loose". At least four fans physically attacked Sludden and struck him with violence. One man who was wearing a red shirt shoved Sludden in the chest before being pursued by television cameras as he made his departure.{{cite news|author1=McGarry, Patsy |author2=Lally, Conor|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0712/1224274518490.html|title=Referee shoved in chest after GAA final|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010|quote=THERE WERE no arrests in Croke Park yesterday despite unruly scenes at the end of the Leinster football final between Louth and Meath in which referee Martin Sludden was pushed and jostled. [...] A man in a red shirt rushed onto the field and shoved the referee in the chest. He was followed by RTÉ cameras as he left the scene.}} Sludden was awarded a [[Garda Síochána|Garda]] escort as he made haste his escape from the pitch. Stadium director Peter McKenna said the referee was "very shaken" after his experience. Louth manager [[Peter Fitzpatrick]] intervened to physically urge the fans to halt their behaviour,{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0711/crokerpark_meath_louth.html |title=Referee is attacked in Croke Park |date=11 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=11 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100712234014/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0711/crokerpark_meath_louth.html |archivedate=12 July 2010 |df= }} an act later described by the ''Irish Independent'' as "a remarkable display of composure from the [[Dundalk]] man, who had every right to be spitting feathers at the defeat". Meath substitute [[Mark Ward (Meath GAA footballer born 1985)|Mark Ward]] was hit by a Louth fan. Children cried and looked sad, and one child allegedly received a wound when hit by a steward. Bottles were hurled from the stands. A steward also received wounds when he was assaulted by a soft drinks bottle. He was given medical attention, and later declared fit to steward further matches. Elsewhere in the stadium, former Meath All-Ireland Senior Football Championship-winning manager [[Seán Boylan]] was involved in an altercation with an irate Louth fan in a corporate box.{{cite news|author=McHale, Michael|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/boylan-plays-down-incident-with-louth-fan-2254940.html|title=Boylan plays down incident with Louth fan|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} Boylan said: "People lose the head all the time" and that he was "more embarrassed than anything". ===Details=== {{football box |date=11 July 2010 |time = 14:00 [[Irish Summer Time|UTC+1]] |team1 = [[Louth GAA|Louth]] |score = 1–10 – 1–12 |report = [http://www.gaa.ie/gaa-news-and-videos/news-archive/1107101654-royals-late-show-breaks-wee-hearts/ (Report)] |team2 = [[Meath GAA|Meath]] |goals1 = P Keenan (0-1), B White (0-4, 3f), A McDonnell (0-1), A Reed (0-1), C Judge (0-2, 1f), JP Rooney (1-1) |goals2 = A Moyles (0-1), N Crawford (0-1), J Sheridan (1-0), G Reilly (0-4), C Ward (0-4, 4f), S Bray (0-2) |stadium = [[Croke Park]], Dublin |attendance = 48,875 |referee = [[Martin Sludden]] }} {| width=92% | |- |{{Football kit |pattern_la = _whiteshoulders |pattern_b = _thinwhitesides |pattern_ra = _whiteshoulders |leftarm = ff0000 |body = ff0000 |rightarm = ff0000 |shorts = FFFFFF |socks = ff0000 |title = Louth }} |{{Football kit |pattern_la = yellowshoulders |pattern_b = _thinyellowsides |pattern_ra = _yellowshoulders |leftarm = 28AE7B |body = 28AE7B |rightarm = 28AE7B |shorts = FFFFFF |socks = 28AE7B |title = Meath }} |} ==View of match participants== ===Joe Sheridan=== Joe Sheridan, who scored the controversial goal, described how he had done it: "It was well-worked and it was a definite goal. People are saying I threw it in, but I was heading for the line and I just dropped the ball and it was in the net. I got it and the lad just pushed me into the net. I tried to do whatever I could to hit it and the goal was given, simple as that. I was pushed in over the line so it should have been a penalty anyway. I think it was a perfect goal". ===Match officials=== Referee Martin Sludden later admitted he had made an error. His referee's report acknowledged a "terrible mistake".{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0715/1224274738230.html|title=Louth move on but sense of injustice persists|date=15 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=15 July 2010|quote=In the light of this and the clear admission in the referee's report that he "made a terrible mistake", the referee's report therefore is questionable. [...] We would contend that the committee/ council in charge erred in leaving the matter to Meath County Board to offer a replay, without seeking clarification from the referee in relation to his match report and his statement "he made a terrible mistake".}} However, based on past refereeing errors, his place on the panel of 18 referees to officiate during the 2010 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship was secure, though the likelihood of him refereeing another match was less so.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/10-key-questions-after-sundays-chaotic-scenes-at-croker-2255907.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130111155028/http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/10-key-questions-after-sundays-chaotic-scenes-at-croker-2255907.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=11 January 2013 |title=10 Key questions after Sunday's chaotic scenes at Croker |date=13 July 2010 |work=[[Irish Independent]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media]] |accessdate=13 July 2010 |df= }} It was thought likely he had been deducted four points from one hundred for his error by his assessor (1 for missing a foul and 3 for Meath profiting from it with a score), though rules banning the assessor from looking at video evidence meant Sludden may not have been deducted any points if the assessor could not see the incident properly from the stand.{{cite news|author1=Kelly, Liam |author2=Foley, Cliona|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/bullish-gilroy-unrepentant-after-depriving-daly-of-dual-star-ocarroll-2262636.html|title=Bullish Gilroy unrepentant after depriving Daly of dual star O'Carroll|date=17 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=17 July 2010}} ===Team managers=== Louth manager Peter Fitzpatrick said he was "absolutely devastated" on RTÉ. Appearing later on radio station [[LMFM]], he described the referee as "[[Dick Turpin]] without a mask", adding "It was pure daylight robbery. I'm very, very annoyed". When questioned at a press conference about Sheridan's goal, Meath manager Eamon O'Brien said: "I can't say and I'm not commenting. I can comment, as I said to RTÉ, that loads of decisions were made during the game that didn't go our way. I can recall three or four balls that were blown for picking off the ground that I didn’t think were off the ground. Nigel Crawford was booked up here and Louth got a point off it. The game goes for 70 minutes, decisions are made and you live with it. That’s it, that’s the way I see it". ===Other players=== Meath's captain Nigel Crawford gave his opinion on the incident: "I'm sure most players have been involved in controversial situations like that where you get calls for replays and things like that happening, but I just don't think it's possible or I just don't think it can happen. If you start that, where do you end up? Do we go back and say the ball wasn’t on the ground when we touched it and they got a free or whatever? It's just very unfortunate that it happens in a high-profile game right at the end of a game to a team that hasn't won in a long time. It's just a very unfortunate situation". Louth player J. P. Rooney said: "Aaron Hoey was pleading with [Sludden] to consult with his umpires but when he went in, he told them to put up the green flag. [...] I know it's wrong, people running at the ref, but you can see why Louth people did it. He brought it on himself and I wouldn't feel sorry for him". ==Reaction== ===Media=== The ''Irish Independent'' said "Meath's Leinster Final goal-that-never-was will go down in history – and not only in Ireland, since by now the images have flashed round the world – among the great injustices suffered in any sport".{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/editorial/gaa-must-play-fair-by-louth-2255101.html|title=GAA must play fair by Louth|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} ''The Irish Times'' described "ugly scenes", with Damian Cullen calling it "one of the strangest endings ever to a GAA match", Seán Moran describing it as "the most extraordinary refereeing error since Jimmy Cooney whistled up early 12 years ago",{{cite news|author=Moran, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0712/1224274518857.html|title=Little sympathy in Meath camp|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010}} and the newspaper publishing numerous letters on the topic from disgruntled members of the public every day that week.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/letters/2010/0713/1224274589427.html|title=Controversy over Leinster final|date=13 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=13 July 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/letters/2010/0714/1224274657571.html|title=Controversy over Leinster final|date=14 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=14 July 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/letters/2010/0715/1224274739007.html|title=Controversy over Leinster final|date=15 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=15 July 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/letters/2010/0716/1224274821598.html|title=Controversy over Leinster final|date=16 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=16 July 2010}} The same newspaper's Philip Reid remarked upon the coincidence that these events had occurred on the same day as the [[2010 FIFA World Cup Final]] in South Africa, wondered why goal-line technology could not be used and added: "On this point, it would appear, the GAA and [[FIFA]] have something in common: they live in the times of the dinosaur".{{cite news|author=Reid, Philip|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0712/1224274518576.html|title=Dark clouds cast over Louth's big day in the sun|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010}} The events in Croke Park led to less prominent newspaper coverage of the FIFA World Cup Final itself the next day. The incident surrounding the goal was likened to [[Thierry Henry]]'s illegal handball in the [[2009 Republic of Ireland vs France football matches|France vs Republic of Ireland 2010 FIFA World Cup play-off]].{{cite news|author=Cullen, Damian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0712/1224274518850.html|title=September Road|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010|quote=AFTER Joe "Thierry Henry" Sheridan's controversial handling of the ball at the end of yesterday's Leinster final, we wracked our brains for some of the other controversial and bizarre endings to GAA matches.}}{{cite news|author=Watterson, Johnny|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0717/1224274900960.html|title=Hold the back page|date=17 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=17 July 2010|quote=The unravelling of the Leinster football final sparked off radical suggestions the match should be replayed and while not as globally embarrassing as the FAI whimpering over the Thierry Henry hand ball, it seemed equally absurd. While Meath diplomacy forbids them to ridicule the "Replayistas" in the manner Fifa boss Sepp Blatter did with the FAI, be sure Meath players bridled at the suggestion.}}{{cite news|author1=Bray, Allison |author2=Keys, Colm |author3=Clarke, Denise |last-author-amp=yes|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/mayhem-and-madness-as-fans-attack-referee-2254900.html|title=Mayhem and madness as fans attack referee|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010|quote=Meath chairman Barney Allen refused to be drawn on a potential offer of a replay afterwards, drawing comparison with the Irish soccer team's plight last November after the Thierry Henry handball. "Ireland didn't get a replay when France got a lucky goal," said Mr Allen.}} Public service broadcaster RTÉ referred to "disgraceful scenes". The GAA website's official match report brushed aside the controversy, saying Sheridan had "smuggled the ball over the line". Eugene McGee, writing in the ''Irish Independent'', said "It will be a stain on the good name of the GAA if this result is allowed to stand".{{cite news|author=McGee, Eugene|url=http://www.independent.ie/opinion/columnists/eugene-mcgee/eugene-mcgee-if-fair-play-exists-in-the-gaa-louth-should-get-their-replay-2254833.html|title=If fair play exists in the gaa, Louth should get their replay|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} His colleague Martin Breheny said there ought to be no replay and that "no sport can run its affairs on the basis of sentiment".{{cite news|author=Breheny, Martin|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/we-cant-replay-gaa-has-no-room-for-sentiment-2257325.html|title=We can't replay – GAA has no room for sentiment|date=14 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=14 July 2010}} ===GAA administrators=== The following day, the GAA released a statement confirming that Sludden admitted he had made an error.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0712/meath_louth1.html |title=Referee admits error in awarding Meath goal |date=12 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=12 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714155354/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0712/meath_louth1.html |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df= }} The GAA also stated that the rules left it powerless to offer a replay and that this would be decided by Meath,{{cite news|author=Moran, Seán|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0712/1224274518866.html|title=Replay only possible if Royal offer is made|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010}} though most Meath players did not wish to facilitate a replay,{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0713/meath_louth.html |title=Royals reluctant to offer Louth replay |date=13 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=13 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714155404/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0713/meath_louth.html |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/northern_ireland/gaelic_games/8812395.stm|title=Louth hopes of replay fade after Meath players say 'no'|date=13 July 2010|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=13 July 2010}} while former Meath players were said to be in favour of one.{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/meath-buy-time-2256002.html|title=Meath buy time. . . but players and management likely to put an end to Louth's replay hopes|date=13 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=13 July 2010}} The GAA said it would work with the authorities to capture Sludden's attackers. [[List of Presidents of the Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA President]] [[Christy Cooney]] said the events were a "watershed" and one where the "circumstances were bizarre. I have never seen circumstances like it as long as I have been a member of this Association".{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0716/cooney.html |title=Cooney – Leinster final a watershed for GAA |date=16 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=16 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100717195114/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0716/cooney.html |archivedate=17 July 2010 |df= }} He promised life bans for those who assaulted the referee.{{cite news|author=Foley, Cliona |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/we-will-impose-life-bans-cooney-2262817.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120802073852/http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/we-will-impose-life-bans-cooney-2262817.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 2 August 2012 |title=We will impose life bans: Cooney |date=17 July 2010 |work=[[Irish Independent]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media]] |accessdate=17 July 2010 |df= }} Croke Park's stadium director Peter McKenna questioned why Louth manager Peter Fitzpatrick had walked onto the pitch to ask the referee about the decision. [[Gaelic Players Association]] (GPA) chief executive [[Dessie Farrell]] said: "What went on last Sunday was a PR disaster for us all".{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/louth-facing-decision-on-use-of-navan-as-home-venue-2260931.html|title=Louth facing decision on use of Navan as 'home' venue|date=16 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=16 July 2010}} The National Referees Committee gave a negative response to the idea of goal-line technology being used in future.{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0713/1224274590243.html|title=Referees in no rush for video technology|date=13 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=13 July 2010}} Retired referee [[John Bannon (referee)|John Bannon]] said "No one deserves to be attacked, either verbally or physically, especially in Croke Park. [...] This attitude still remains part of the GAA's culture, it has never been rooted out".{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/who-said-what-2255909.html|title=Who said what . . .|date=13 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=13 July 2010}} [[Tyrone GAA|Tyrone]] County Board (from where the referee originated) sympathised with the Sludden but said the crowd's reaction was "unbelievable".{{cite news|author=Cahill, Jackie|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/red-hand-chairman-standing-by-underfire-ref-sludden-2259098.html|title=Red Hand chairman standing by under-fire ref Sludden|date=15 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=15 July 2010}} [[Liam O'Neill]], a candidate for the GAA presidency in 2012, later said: "Quite simply, there should have been a re-fixture for that game. Everyone knows that. Everyone knows a wrong was perpetrated".{{cite news|author=Cummiskey, Gavin|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0721/1224275144935.html|title=O'Neill calls for change to five-year term on playing laws|date=21 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=21 July 2010}} ===GAA personalities=== There was significant public and analytical support for Louth and condemnation of the refereeing decision.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0712/meath_louth.html |title=Massive support for Wee County |date=12 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=12 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714155349/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0712/meath_louth.html |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df= }} On ''[[The Sunday Game]]'' TV highlights programme, [[Pat Spillane]] called both the fans and the referee "disgraceful", commenting: {{cquote|Those were disgraceful scenes at the end. Cowardly individuals attacking a referee who is doing it in a voluntary capacity. There is no place in the GAA for people like that. Scandalous scenes and a bad day for the GAA on that account. A fella doing a job made a human error. He made a mistake. We cannot condone those scenes, they are disgraceful and punishments must be handed out. However, just as disgraceful is that Louth were robbed of their first Leinster title since 1957 by a complete refereeing mistake. Joe Sheridan threw the ball over the line. Under any rules of the game, experimental or not, the goal should not have been allowed.}} Former Meath player [[Trevor Giles]] said: "If this victory stands, it won't do Meath any favours because there will always be a question mark over the result". Former [[Kerry GAA|Kerry]] footballer [[Darragh Ó Sé]] described the idea of Meath County Board having the final decision on a replay as "a complete and utter cop-out".{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0714/1224274657319.html|title=Controversies highlight that the GAA must start to show some direction|date=14 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=14 July 2010}} Former Kerry footballer and manager [[Páidí Ó Sé]] said: "there is no way any referee should have allowed Sheridan's goal to stand".{{cite news|author=Ó Sé, Páidí|author-link=Páidí Ó Sé|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/in-sport-you-have-to-take-the-rough-with-the-smooth-2263257.html|title=In sport, you have to take the rough with the smooth|date=18 July 2010|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=18 July 2010}} [[Sligo GAA|Sligo]] footballer [[Eamonn O'Hara]] suggested that the events gave "the perfect opportunity [for the GAA] to revamp the way match-day officials are selected".{{cite news|author=O'Hara, Eamonn|author-link=Eamonn O'Hara|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/leinster-final-chaos-presents-perfect-chance-to-revamp-umpire-selection-2263884.html|title=Leinster final chaos presents perfect chance to revamp umpire selection|date=19 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=19 July 2010}} Veteran commentator [[Mícheál Ó Muircheartaigh]] told [[Ryan Tubridy]] on [[The Tubridy Show|his radio show]] that "Croke Park abdicated responsibility. They should have taken the matter from Meath".{{cite news|author=Keane, Billy|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/gaarsquos-abdication-of-responsibility-towards-royals-has-tarnished-their-leinster-crown-2262810.html|title=GAA's abdication of responsibility towards Royals has tarnished their Leinster crown|date=17 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=17 July 2010}} ===Politicians=== [[Minister for Justice and Equality|Minister for Justice and Law Reform]] [[Dermot Ahern]], himself from Louth, made known his condemnation of the violence.{{cite news|url=http://www.examiner.ie/breakingnews/ireland/justice-minister-condemns-altercations-at-gaa-game-465189.html|title=Justice Minister condemns altercations at GAA game|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|publisher=[[Thomas Crosbie Holdings]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} He attended the match.{{cite news|author1=Parsons, Michael |author2=Minihan, Mary|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/0713/1224274589396.html|title=Ahern deplores Croke Park scenes|date=13 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=13 July 2010}} [[Taoiseach]] [[Brian Cowen]] also made known his disapproval later from New York: "I didn't see what happened as the ref was leaving the pitch. But obviously none of that is justified. It was an exciting match obviously. But it doesn't justify anyone engaging in that sort of activity. So I wouldn't like to see it repeated anywhere". Cowen was also at the match. ===Other=== The [[Garda Síochána]] announced that it would investigate those persons they said breached the Non-fatal Offences Against the Person Act by battering the referee and others.{{cite news|author1=Cusack, Jim |author2=Lawlor, Damian|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/gardai-close-in-on-croker-prosecutions-2263264.html|title=Gardaí close in on Croker prosecutions|date=18 July 2010|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=18 July 2010}} Bookmaker [[Boylesports]] paid all losing bets on the match.{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/bookies-handout-eases-louth-pain-2254846.html|title=Bookies' handout eases Louth pain|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} ==Outcome== On 13 July, Louth's county executive committee issued a statement condemning what it described as "the unsavoury incidents after the match".{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0713/louth_meath.html |title=Louth condemn Croke Park attack |date=13 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=13 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100714155359/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0713/louth_meath.html |archivedate=14 July 2010 |df= }} Meath's county board gathered in [[Navan]] but did not issue an immediate statement, instead requesting more time to think.{{cite news|author1=Keys, Colm |author2=McHale, Michael |url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/meath-call-for-extra-time-over-louth-replay-bid-2255978.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130108004530/http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/meath-call-for-extra-time-over-louth-replay-bid-2255978.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 8 January 2013 |title=Meath call for extra time over Louth replay bid |date=13 July 2010 |work=[[Irish Independent]] |publisher=[[Independent News & Media]] |accessdate=13 July 2010 |df= }}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0712/1224274552634.html|title=Meath county board asks for more time|date=12 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=12 July 2010}}{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0713/1224274590229.html|title=Meath's deferral of final decision makes chance of replay less likely|date=13 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=13 July 2010}} They later decided that there would be no replay, this would be "the end of the matter".{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0713/1224274613334.html|title=Meath decide against offering replay|date=13 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=13 July 2010}} Meath were officially champions of Leinster for 2010,{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0714/1224274680949.html|title=Louth left to ponder options|date=14 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=14 July 2010|quote=In the end they delivered on the greater expectation that the result must, under GAA rule, still stand, and that, as far as they were concerned, "was the end of the matter". It means Meath go forward as Leinster football champions, in name at least.}}{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0714/1224274660841.html|title=Meath rule out replay to leave Louth pondering options|date=14 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=14 July 2010}} though Meath secretary Cyril Creavin conceded that it was a "tainted" title and that "Some of the players are devastated with the reaction in newspapers".{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/louths-legal-move-2257402.html|title=Louth's legal move|date=14 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=14 July 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/northern_ireland/gaelic_games/8820138.stm|title=Louth hopes of replay end as Meath board says 'no'|date=14 July 2010|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=14 July 2010}} Louth accepted this: their official statement referred to the [[July 2010 R238 traffic collision]] which occurred on the same day as the final, sympathising with relatives of the eight people killed, and opting to avoid legal action in such a context. Therefore, Meath automatically entered the quarter-finals of the [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]], with Louth left to qualify for that same stage by playing (and winning) a further game in Round 4{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/game-at-a-glance-2254832.html|title=GAME AT A GLANCE|date=12 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=12 July 2010}} of the All-Ireland qualifiers.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0714/1224274728235.html|title=Louth to take no further action|date=14 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=14 July 2010|quote=“Finally, in light of [[July 2010 R238 traffic collision|the tragic events which occurred in Donegal over the weekend]] we realise that we must put our situation in context and we would like to extend our deepest sympathies to the family and friends of those deceased."}} Louth were drawn against [[Dublin GAA|Dublin]] in their next game.{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0719/1224275061957.html|title=Louth get Croke Park date with Dublin|date=19 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=19 July 2010}}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0719/1224275033301.html|title=Louth draw qualifier date with Dublin|date=19 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=19 July 2010}}{{cite news|author=O'Riordan, Ian|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0719/1224275017767.html|title=Roscommon shine once again as Sligo can't live up to expectations|date=19 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=19 July 2010|quote=The big question about the Dublin-Louth pairing is how well Louth can recover from last Sunday's Leinster final fiasco against Meath, because unless they come out fighting again, Dublin have a great chance of making the All-Ireland quarter-final.}}{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0721/1224275145109.html|title=Fitzpatrick delighted with 'dream' draw|date=21 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=21 July 2010}}{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/louth-must-pick-up-pieces-as-resurgent-dublin-await-in-qualifiers-2263873.html|title=Louth must pick up pieces as resurgent Dublin await in qualifiers|date=19 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=19 July 2010}} The appointment of experienced referee [[Pat McEnaney]] was scrutinised and praised in advance.{{cite news|author=Keys, Colm|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/mcenaney-to-take-charge-of-louthdublin-croker-clash-2265916.html|title=McEnaney to take charge of Louth-Dublin Croker clash|date=21 July 2010|work=[[Irish Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=21 July 2010|quote=McEnaney's appointment will be viewed as a secure option after the dramatic and tension-filled scenes at the end of the Leinster football final at the same venue 10 days ago.}} In the game, held once again at Croke Park on 24 July,{{cite news|author=Cummiskey, Gavin|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/sport/2010/0720/1224275073430.html|title=It's double headers back to back|date=20 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=20 July 2010|quote=The Dublin footballers, as expected and despite the low turnouts for their recent victories over Tipperary and Armagh, are back in Croke Park for a fifth time this season, and third successive week, as they attempt to salvage their campaign against Louth. That means the defeated Leinster finalists must return to the scene of the crime that saw referee Martin Sludden assaulted by supporters after the provincial decider against Meath on July 11th.}} Louth were defeated by 2–14 to 0–13, thus being eliminated from the [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship 2010|2010 All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]].{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sports/gaa/2010/0724/1224275433712.html|title=Dublin show no sympathy|date=24 July 2010|work=[[The Irish Times]]|publisher=Irish Times Trust|accessdate=24 July 2010|quote=Moral champions of Leinster they maybe but Louth are out of the All-Ireland football championship after being comprehensively beaten by Dublin at Croke Park. Two weeks after being denied a provincial title by a very bad call against Meath, the Wee County can have few complaints this time round.}}{{cite news|author=Crowe, Dermot|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-football/dubs-finally-warming-to-summer-task-2271850.html|title=Dubs finally warming to summer task|date=25 July 2010|work=[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]|publisher=[[Independent News & Media]]|accessdate=25 July 2010|quote=Two weeks after they were stunned in the Leinster final, Louth still looked punch-drunk as the Dubs raced into an early lead, boosted by a goal from Eoghan O'Gara. They never recovered and the game limped to an inevitable conclusion. After the final whistle they went on a lap of honour to offer appreciation to their followers after the longest summer the county has witnessed in over half a century.}} By defeating Louth, Dublin joined Meath in the quarter-finals of the All-Ireland Senior Football Championship.{{cite news|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0724/dublin_louth.html |title=Dublin 2–14 Louth 0–13 |date=24 July 2010 |work=[[RTÉ Sport]] |publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann]] |accessdate=24 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100724232452/http://www.rte.ie/sport/gaa/championship/2010/0724/dublin_louth.html |archivedate=24 July 2010 |df= }} For Louth so ended "the longest summer the county has witnessed in over half a century". ==TV== On 15 September 2014, "A Wee Royal Rumble - The Story of the 2010 Leinster Football Final" was broadcast on [[RTÉ One]] as part of ''[[Scannal]]'', the TV series dedicated to scandalous events.{{cite news|url=http://www.hoganstand.com/ArticleForm.aspx?ID=224348|title=If it happened to Meath I'm sure the referee would have ended up in the canal|work=Hogan Stand|date=15 September 2014|accessdate=15 September 2014}} ==Further reading== * Hogan, Vincent. {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Al-Shaab Stadium | nickname = ملعب الشعب الدولي | image = [[Image:Al-Shaab Stadium3 (3).JPG|300px]] | fullname = Al-Shaab Stadium | location = [[Baghdad]], [[Iraq]] | coordinates = {{coord|33|19|29.53|N|44|26|7.09|E|type:landmark_region:IQ_scale:2000|display=it}} | broke_ground = 21 April 1960 | built = 1960–1966 (6 years) | opened = 6 November 1966 | renovated = 2005, 2010, 2015 | expanded = | closed = 2003–2005, 2009–2010 | reopened = | demolished = | owner = [[Government of Iraq]] | surface = Grass and track | construction_cost = [[Iraqi dinar|IQD]] 1,200,000 (1966) | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = [[Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation]] | main_contractors = Tahsin Nu'man Rif'at | former_names = | tenants = [[Al Shorta SC]] (2014–present)
[[Al-Zawra'a SC]] (2012–present)
[[Iraq national football team]] (1966–2013)
[[1985 Arab Club Champions Cup]]
[[1982 Arab Club Champions Cup]]
[[5th Arabian Gulf Cup]] | seating_capacity = 34,200
{{cite web|last1=Al-Mashhadani|first1=Akram|title=Story of Al-Shaab stadium.. An Iraqi monument that won't be rebuilt|url=http://www.ishtartv.com/viewarticle,64637.html|website=Ishtar Channel|language=Arabic|date=27 November 2015}} | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} '''Al-Shaab Stadium''' ({{lang-ar|ملعب الشعب}}; translates to ''The People's Stadium'') is an [[All-seater stadium|All-seater]] [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Baghdad]]. The 34,200 seater was the home stadium of the [[Iraq national football team]] from its opening on 6 November 1966 until the [[Basra Sports City|Basra International Stadium]] was opened in 2013. The stadium is owned by the government of Iraq. Al-Shaab stadium hosted the [[5th Arabian Gulf Cup]], the [[Arab Club Champions Cup]] in [[1982 Arab Club Champions Cup|1982]]{{cite web|title=1st Arab Club Champions Cup 1982 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/arabchamp82.html |website=RSSSF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104053403/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/arabchamp82.html |archivedate=2013-11-04 |df= }} and [[1985 Arab Club Champions Cup|1985]],{{cite web|title=3rd Arab Club Champions Cup 1985 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/arabchamp85.html |website=RSSSF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131104090550/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/arabchamp85.html |archivedate=2013-11-04 |df= }} the [[1972 Palestine Cup of Nations]] and the [[World Military Cup]] on two occasions: in 1968 and 1972.{{cite web|title=World Military Championship|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesm/military.html|website=RSSSF}} Al-Shaab stadium was the largest stadium in Iraq until the [[Basra Sports City|Basra International Stadium]], that has the capacity of 65,000 spectators, was opened in 2013.{{cite web|title=Stadiums in Iraq|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/middle_east/countries/iraq.shtml|website=World Stadiums}} == History == === Construction === [[File:Al-Shaab Stadium during construction.jpg|thumbnail|left|Al-Shaab Stadium under construction in 1965.]] In late 1959, a delegation from the [[Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation]] visited Former [[Prime Minister of Iraq|Prime Minister]] [[Abd al-Karim Qasim]] in his office, which was in the [[Ministry of Defense (Iraq)|Ministry of Defense]]. The meeting contained an offer that the foundation presented to the government of Iraq. It was assigning a percentage of the steady grant of oil that is owned by the foundation to build projects in Baghdad. These projects included the [[Iraqi National Museum]], the [[Iraqi National Theater]], the [[Baghdad Medical City|Medical City]] and Al-Shaab Stadium.{{cite web|last1=al-Badrawi|first1=Ali|title=Al-Shaab Stadium|url=http://forum.kooora.com/f.aspx?t=34883257|website=Kooora Forums|language=Arabic}} Abd al-Karim Qasim announced the building of Al-Shaab stadium on 21 April 1960, in front of 15,000 spectators. He said that the building of the new official stadium of the [[Iraq national football team]] will end in 1962 and will have the capacity of 50,000 spectators.{{cite journal|title=Al-Shaab Stadium in the announcement of the leader|journal=Al-Bilad|date=June 1960|issue=Special|language=Arabic}} The cost of construction was 1 million dinars, for the stadium to be one of the biggest in the middle east. Its total area is 200,000m² with the capacity of 34,200 spectators. It had an athletics track covered with [[Tartan]], lighting towers with the height of 55 meters and the total area of the park is 40,000m² with the capacity of 4,000 cars. The complex had two training stadiums, basketball, volleyball, handball and tennis fields and also it contained an Olympic swimming pool.{{cite web|title=Complete Biography of Al-Shaab Stadium|url=http://www.shakwmakw.com/vb/showthread.php?t=3857|website=ShakwMakw|language=Arabic}} === Opening === The opening match of Al-Shaab stadium was between the Portuguese team, [[S.L. Benfica]]., and a team that composed of the best players in Baghdad.{{cite web|title=Opening of Al-Shaab Stadium|url=http://salamshabab.com/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%82-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%AB%D9%84-%D9%87%D8%B0%D8%A7-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD-%D9%85%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4/|website=Salam Shabab|language=Arabic|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216032421/http://salamshabab.com/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%82-%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D8%AB%D9%84-%D9%87%D8%B0%D8%A7-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AD-%D9%85%D9%84%D8%B9%D8%A8-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B4/|archivedate=2016-02-16|df=}} 60,000 spectators attended the match in Al-Shaab Stadium that could only hold the maximum capacity of 50,000. 30 minutes into the game, [[José Augusto Torres]] scored for Benfica. In the second half, [[Qasim Mahmoud]] scored for the Baghdad team at the 55th minute, tying up the game. Benfica made it 2–1 at the 80th minute from a shot by [[Domiciano Cavém]].{{cite web|title=THE OPENING GAME AT AL-SHAAB: THE DAY EUSEBIO CAME TO BAGHDAD|url=https://iraqsport.wordpress.com/2014/01/05/the-opening-game-at-al-shaab-the-day-eusebio-came-to-baghdad/|website=HASSANIN MUBARAK'S BLOG}} {{Footballbox collapsible |date = 6 November 1966 |time = |team1 = Baghdad XI {{flagicon|Iraq|1963}} |score = 1–2 |report = [https://iraqsport.wordpress.com/2014/01/05/the-opening-game-at-al-shaab-the-day-eusebio-came-to-baghdad Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|Portugal}} [[S.L. Benfica]] |goals1 = [[Qasim Mahmoud|Mahmoud]] {{goal|55}} |goals2 = [[José Augusto Torres|Torres]] {{goal|30}}
[[Domiciano Cavém|Cavém]] {{goal|80}} |stadium = Al-Shaab Stadium, [[Baghdad]] |attendance = 60,000 |referee = Fahmi al-Qaimaqchi ([[Iraq Football Association|Iraq]]) }} === Crisis === On 9 April 2003, Al-Shaab stadium was largely damaged after it got bombed by the [[U.S. Air Force]] during the [[Battle of Baghdad (2003)]]. Most of its seats were destroyed and many large holes were made inside the pitch. Until 2004, the stadium was used as an airstrip for the U.S. Air Force.{{cite web|title=Stadium didn't survive the invasion|url=http://www.kademalsahir.com/vb/showthread.php?t=14355|website=KademalSahir|language=Arabic}} Therefor, in April 2004, the [[Coalition Provisional Authority]] Chief Administrator, [[Paul Bremer]], announced that $3 million would be given to renovate Al-Shaab Stadium and to make it in a good condition for hosting different sports.{{cite news|last1=Harris|first1=Kent|title=Iraqi athletes have Olympic dreams|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/iraqi-athletes-have-olympic-dreams-1.18451|agency=Stars and Stripes|date=5 April 2004}} The stadium was officially reopened after 2003, on 12 June 2005, being ready to host some of the [[2005-06 Iraqi Premier League]] matches.{{cite web|title=Reopening Al-Shaab Stadium|url=http://www.ankawa.com/forum/index.php?topic=850.0|website=Ankawa|language=Arabic}} [[Iraq national football team]] couldn't play in Al-Shaab stadium from 2005 to 2009 because of the [[Iraqi insurgency (2003–11)|Iraqi Civil War]]. Iraq's first match in the stadium, after six years of playing the home matches in other countries, was on 13 July 2009, where Iraq met [[Palestine national football team|Palestine]] in an [[International friendly]] and won 4-0.{{cite news|last1=Myers|first1=Steven Lee|title=Iraqis Cheer for a Team That Again Is at Home|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/14/world/middleeast/14soccer.html?_r=1&|agency=[[The New York Times]]|date=13 June 2009}} === Renovations === [[File:Al-Shaab Stadium (25).JPG|thumb|right|Stands of Al-Shaab Stadium in December 2010]] Companies started the renovation of Al-Shaab stadium on 2 March 2010 with a cost of $3,966,000 from the expense of the [[Prime Minister of Iraqi Kurdistan]] [[Nechervan Barzani]].{{cite web|title=al-Shaab stadium reconstruction |url=http://www.aliraqi.org/forums/showthread.php?t=98722 |website=Al Iraqi |language=Arabic }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The renovation included replacing the grass with an evergreen grass, the athletics track with a new one that consists of the blue and white colors and also replacing the seats with yellow, green, blue and grey colored new ones. The renovation was made by English, Swedish and Russian companies. It was finished on 9 May 2010.{{cite web|title=End of the renovation of Al-Shaab Stadium |url=http://www.iraqimate.com/vb/showthread.php?t=63744 |website=Al-Multaqa al-Iraqi |language=Arabic }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In May 2015, companies cooperated with the Ministry of Youth in renovating the stadium and making it in a good form before a delegation from [[FIFA]] visits Iraq to rate Al-Shaab stadium and the [[Basra Sports City|Basra International Stadium]] to start lifting the ban from Iraqi stadiums.{{cite news|title=Ministry of Youth starts the last steps of renovating Al-Shaab Stadium|url=http://www.ara.shafaaq.com/4632|agency=Shafaq News|date=30 May 2015|language=Arabic|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150603232127/http://www.ara.shafaaq.com/4632|archivedate=3 June 2015|df=}} The renovation included painting the main compartment, putting ceramic floors, reestablish the electric system of the stadium, re-qualifying the park and the outside area of the stadium, putting electric doors and fixing the elevators to the compartments.{{cite news|title=Ministry of Youth start the last steps of renovating Al-Shaab Stadium|url=http://hamrinnews.net/Now/50506.html|agency=Hamrin News|date=30 May 2015|language=Arabic}} On 5 August 2015, the administrative company that is responsible of renovating Al-Shaab stadium announced that on 15 August, the renovation continued after it was paused from June to August; because of the [[2014–15 Iraqi Premier League|Iraqi Premier League]].{{cite news|title=Renovation of Al-Shaab stadium starts in mid-August|url=http://hamrinnews.net/s/42632.html|agency=Hamrin News|date=August 5, 2015|language=Arabic}} They included replacing the sprinkling system and replacing the pitch, depending on the basis of high-quality international stadiums.{{cite news|title=Removal of Al-Shaab stadium's pitch in mid-August|url=http://hamrinnews.net/n/42582.html|agency=Hamrin News|date=August 7, 2015|language=Arabic}} == Tournaments hosted == === World Military Cup === Al-Shaab stadium hosted the [[World Military Cup]] of 1968 and 1972, where the [[Iraq military national football team]] didn't pass the qualification round in 1968, but in 1972, Iraq became champions after finishing in the top of the league at 6 points, above [[Italy military national football team|Italy]]. === 1972 Palestine Cup of Nations === Al-Shaab stadium hosted the [[1972 Palestine Cup of Nations]], where [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] were the runners-up of [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]] after finishing in top of Group A in the groups stage at 5 points.{{cite web|title=Palestine Cup 1972 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesp/palestine71.html |website=RSSSF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110921173638/http://www.rsssf.com/tablesp/palestine71.html |archivedate=2011-09-21 |df= }} Iraq won over [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in the semi-final 3-1 by the goals of [[Shamil Kamil]] (2 goals) and [[Ali Kadhim]] for Iraq and [[Mustafa Dahleb]] for Algeria. In the final, Iraq lost 1-3 against Egypt by the goals of [[Douglas Aziz]] for Iraq and [[Hassan El-Shazly]] and [[Abdul-Aziz Abdul-Shafi]] (2 goals) for Egypt. === 5th Arabian Gulf Cup === [[File:Opening ceremony of the 1979 Gulf Cup.webm|thumbnail|right|Clips from the opening ceremony of the [[5th Arabian Gulf Cup]] in Al-Shaab Stadium.]] Al-Shaab stadium hosted the [[5th Arabian Gulf Cup]], where it was one of the best hosts in the history of the [[Arabian Gulf Cup]]. The past [[Iraqi President]] [[Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr]] was represented by [[Izzat Ibrahim al-Douri]] in the opening ceremony on 23 March 1979.{{cite web|title=Clips of the opening of the 5th Gulf Cup in Iraq|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9ZTRtRSz6IY|website=Youtube|language=Arabic}} The opening ceremony was organized and well planned. The first match, after the opening ceremony, was between the hosts, [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] and [[Bahrain national football team|Bahrain]] that ended in a 4-0 win for Iraq.{{cite web|title=Bahrain 0-4 Iraq - Gulf Cup Website|url=http://www.gulfcup.com/soccer/matches/matcha.php?match_id=195&period=5|website=Gulf Cup|language=Arabic}} This tournament ended with the hosts as the champions, breaking the streak of [[Kuwait national football team|Kuwait]] in winning the Gulf Cup for 4 consecutive tournaments, from 1972 to 1979.{{cite web|title=Golden Record - Gulf Cup Website|url=http://www.gulfcup.com/gulfcup/indexa.php?page=gold_record_a.php|website=Gulf Cup Website|language=Arabic}} === 1982 Arab Club Champions Cup Final === Al-Shaab stadium hosted both legs of the final of the first ever [[Arab Club Champions Cup]] in [[1980–82 Arab Club Champions Cup|1982]], where Iraqi club [[Al Shorta SC]] were the champions after beating Lebanese club [[Nejmeh SC]] in the first leg of the final 2–0 and drew with them in the second leg 2–2. Al Shorta were awarded in the stadium, being one of the two Iraqi teams who ever won the Arab Club Champions Cup competition. The other team was [[Al-Rasheed]].{{cite web|title=Arab Club Champions Cup - Palmares|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesa/arabchamp.html|website=RSSSF}} === 1985 Arab Club Champions Cup === Al-Shaab hosted the third tournament of the [[Arab Club Champions Cup]] in [[1985 Arab Club Champions Cup|1985]], where [[Al-Karkh SC|Al-Rasheed]] became the champions, after they ended in top of the league in the final stage at 4 points. They beat [[Nejmeh SC]], on 5 December 1985, with a big 6-1 win. On 9 December, they beat Algerian club [[USM El Harrach]] with a 2-1 result. Al-Rasheed also won [[1986 Arab Club Champions Cup]] and the [[1987 Arab Club Champions Cup|1987]] one. == Important matches == === 31 March 1980 – Kuwait === Al-Shaab stadium hosted the matches of Group 1 for the [[1980 Asian Olympic Qualifying Tournaments]], where Round 1 ended with [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] in the top of the league and [[Kuwait national football team|Kuwait]] in 2nd place.{{cite web|title=Games of the XXII. Olympiad - Football Qualifying Tournament |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tableso/ol1980q.html#Asia |website=RSSSF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130315030624/http://rsssf.com/tableso/ol1980q.html |archivedate=2013-03-15 |df= }} In the playoff match between Iraq and Kuwait, 65,000 spectators arrived at the stadium. Iraq ended the first half with the score being 2-0. The goals were scored by [[Nizar Ashraf]] at the 6th and 44th minutes.{{cite web|last1=al-Rantissi|first1=Abdul Fattah|title=Matches from History 1 - Kuwait vs. Iraq 1980|url=http://forum.kooora.com/f.aspx?t=28354036|website=Kooora Forums|language=Arabic}} In the second half, the Kuwaitis had an uprising, scoring three goals in 13 minutes. The goals were from [[Jasem Yaqoub]] at the 69th minute, [[Nassir Al-Ghanim]] at the 79th minute and Yaqoub again in the 82nd minute, qualifying Kuwait into the [[Football at the 1980 Summer Olympics|1980 Summer Olympics]].{{cite web|title=Story of the match between Iraq and Kuwait at the Olympics qualifying tournaments|url=http://diwania.alazraq.com/showthread.php?t=109546|website=Al-Azraq|language=Arabic}} However, Iraq still qualified to the Olympics after [[Malaysia national football team|Malaysia]] withdrew. === February 1986 – Denmark League XI === After [[FIFA]] lifted the ban from Iraqi soil, because of the [[Iraq-Iran war]], the [[Iraqi Football Association]] sent an invitation to the [[Dansk Boldspil-Union]] for a friendly in Baghdad and in Al-Shaab stadium. The DBU sent the [[Denmark League XI national football team]] to play against [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] in two matches regarded by FIFA and IFA as A internationals, but it wasn't regarded as such by the DBU.{{cite web|title=Iraq - Denmark League XI 1986|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iraq-intres86.html|website=RSSSF}} The first match was on 1 February, where the Danish team was on top of its game, unlike the Iraqi team, which had lots of gaps and mistakes, resulting in an early goal in the 6th minute from [[Claus Nielsen]] and another one in the 33rd minute from [[Jan Bartram]]. In the second match, Iraq dominated the whole match, scoring a goal from [[Hussein Saeed]] just before halftime from a penalty and another one from [[Natiq Hashim Abidoun]] in the 63rd minute. {{Footballbox collapsible |date = 1 February 1986 |time = |team1 = {{flagicon|Iraq|1963}} [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] |score = 0–2 |report = [http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iraq-intres86.html Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Denmark League XI national football team|Denmark League XI]] |goals1 = |goals2 = [[Claus Nielsen|Nielsen]] {{goal|6}}
[[Jan Bartram|Bartram]] {{goal|33}} |stadium = Al-Shaab Stadium, [[Baghdad]] |attendance = 45,000 |referee = {{flagicon|Iraq|1963}} Farouk Tawfiq }} {{Footballbox collapsible |date = 3 February 1986 |time = |team1 = {{flagicon|Iraq|1963}} [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] |score = 2–0 |report = [http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iraq-intres86.html Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Denmark League XI national football team|Denmark League XI]] |goals1 = [[Hussein Saeed|Saeed]] ([[Penalty kick (association football)|pen]].) {{goal|45}}
[[Natiq Hashim Abidoun|Hashim]] {{goal|63}} |goals2 = |stadium = Al-Shaab Stadium, [[Baghdad]] |attendance = 45,000 |referee = {{flagicon|Iraq|1963}} Salah Abdul-Karim }} === 10 February 1989 – Qatar === Al-Shaab stadium hosted the home match of [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]] against [[Qatar national football team|Qatar]] in the [[1990 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)]], where Iraq needed to win because they were only one point away from first placed Qatar.{{cite web|title=World Cup 1990 Qualifying|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tables/90q.html|website=RSSSF}} Iraq and Qatar started the match with rain showering on its ground. In the first half, Iraq were the better side, but because of the slippery ground, the Iraqi defense made some mistakes resulting in a goal for Qatar from [[Saleh Eid al-Mehaizaa]] in the 18th minute.{{cite web|title=Results of 1989|url=http://niiiis.com/r1989.html|website=Iraqi Football Archive|language=Arabic}} [[Ahmed Radhi]] equalized the score from a header in the 31st minute. In the second half, Iraq controlled the match completely with Qatar wasting time in hope for a draw. But, from counter-attack led by Radhi and [[Hussein Saeed]], Saeed scored his last goal with Iraq, being the most goals scorer for Iraq at 78 goals. In the 85th minute, Qatar equalized the score, after the Iraqi audience at Al-Shaab Stadium were sure of their national team claiming the win, by [[Adel Khamis]]. The match ended in a 2-2 draw, which qualified Qatar to the next round of the qualifications. After this match, the Iraqi golden team of the 80s ended with the retiring of [[Khalil Allawi]], [[Ali Hussein Shihab]], [[Basil Gorgis]], [[Ghanim Oraibi]], [[Ahmad Jassim]] and [[Hussein Saeed]]. == References == {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{commons category|Al-Shaab Stadium}} * [http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/middle_east/iraq/baghdad_shaab.shtml World Stadiums: Al-Shaab Stadium] * [http://www.worldstadia.com/stadium/iraq/al_shaab_stadium/1744.php World Stadia: Al-Shaab Stadium] [[Category:Football venues in Iraq]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Baghdad]] [[Category:Sport in Baghdad]] [[Category:National stadiums|Iraq]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Iraq]] [[Category:1966 establishments in Iraq]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1966]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox model | name = Alena Šeredová | image = Alena Seredova.jpg | caption = Alena Šeredová | birth_name = Alena Šeredová | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1978|3|21}} | birth_place = [[Prague]], [[Czechoslovakia]]
{{small|(now [[Czech Republic]])}} | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = {{ubl|{{marriage|[[Gianluigi Buffon]]|2011|2014}}}} | partner = Alessandro Nasi | height = {{height|m=1.81|precision=0}} | eye_color = Dark brown | hair_color = Dark brown (originally black) | skin_color = | website = http://www.alenaseredova.it/ | children = 2 }} '''Alena Seredova''' ({{IPA-cs|ˈalɛna ˈʃɛrɛdovaː}}; born 21 March 1978 [[Prague]]) is a [[Czech people|Czech]] model and actress currently living and working in Italy. == Career == Alena's modeling career started at the age of 15. Five years later, Alena was first runner-up of [[Miss Czech Republic]] 1998 and her country's representative at [[Miss World 1998]] where she placed fourth equal in the finals. She started her career as a model in 2002. Alena was chosen by the Italian comedian Giorgio Panariello to co-host his own prime-time TV show ''Torno Sabato''. Alena has been featured on the covers of several magazines including ''[[Penthouse (magazine)|Penthouse]] Europe'', ''[[Playboy (magazine)|Playboy]] Europe'', ''[[Spy (magazine)|Spy]]'', ''[[Extreme (magazine)|Extreme]]'' and ''Quo''. In 2005, Alena was chosen to pose in Max Calendar.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1564364/bio?ref_=nm_ov_bio_sm|title=Alena Seredova Biography|work=imdb.com|accessdate=26 December 2013}} == Personal life == Alena was married to Italian national football goalkeeper [[Gianluigi Buffon]]. They have a son named Louis Thomas Buffon, who was born on 28 December 2007. Their second son, David Lee was born on 1 November 2009, in Milano, Italy. In May 2014 Buffon announced his separation from Šeredová.{{cite news|title=Alena e Gigi oggi sposi|url=http://www.juventus.com/wps/portal/it/news/buffon%20seredova%20sposi%2016giugno2011/!ut/p/b1/rZHJjqNKFES_pT6gmgRshmVmMpnJxWQwG4vZYDAuJ5Pz659ber3s7k3fTehKR4pQBJMyCZPes6Vtsqkd71n_80-FCydA2bd0FkiBh8FBkCCIQsxKO5GJmcQoXptSOI0KFXiKm1HNKRLwjV4n4FewjRV8bdILq1qZtJ8LIrPu_R5w-8IoS3dMuTa0dt-1lyb0NfenaWhc6cRVNBX0XYxolVhTACzvS9DFztX0NkkWYJlFP7eHVar8JIzx0QG433wsuGF81R2yPm9tUXeY5gHQwQdjMulaDD_a6ce9Wglz6s5gU8d3YDVezs9jT77Twy3Yy8qgEE8zTOgsEM45d04O-PtyuVORXjYcVoh3dxDacdxUHW9jD9JXKXu31ddGdJKGYAGqYs9-Wm05XfYrMQn6sp_jtsQafHJzd3J3nNTzQZTJUWoW2CyPrizzN7503I3VCpWtpqjrstAnI3l6ExHNAYem1UteYaJPWfJnUzjbUT_VFF1o_VSaj_cA6R83ksD_APjNQcC4xjhUzPmNiRcOAF1GLAQ6byNwiCzNsJHIHnccEzIJ2F2C7vU40Bv1O-pbJNpcV30BoHKbq3z5bq6CacKsY0cr20VbeCN0CiEgoUcdN_wqT36EIArta-P8MvxNcFv4adgVLMLksKqq4hO-hYP6CsI2t8EYRVrpfYNhjwm6P8Z2jLXwJT-DeoT1_kIehpt7rYu3B63ZdvE0nbXZwOytJSSekp2VJuFEbLOir5bNpo85rp65kh2ROt1kBRooOnd4CKfI2SfLO2A8e2TX36t7zbMU-ae6Kl87Pbs6VZ9x8RTvpdZH1rSJxnpt_D49eG9sQHJ2hfLgC59zYBuUN8T5vdlfmmb_edOPYRnkw6e-vLWBHx__Ac7uBqw!/dl4/d5/L2dBISEvZ0FBIS9nQSEh/?urile=wcm%3apath%3a%2fjuvecom-it%2fnews%2fbuffon%20seredova%20sposi%2016giugno2011|publisher=juventus.com|date=16 June 2011|language=Italian}} She has a sister named Eliška, who is also a model. Her mother's name is Jitka Šeredová. Alena co-owns the Italian clothing-line (Baci e Abbracci) together with Buffon's former national teammate, [[Christian Vieri]].{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/2008/dicembre/12/Baci_Abbracci_Bobo_servono_altri_mo_0_081212025.shtml|title=Né Baci né Abbracci, a Bobo servono altri soci|publisher=Il Corriere della Sera|language=Italian|author1=Daniela Polizzi|author2=Carlo Turchetti|date=12 December 2008|accessdate=7 January 2016}} As of 2014 Alena Šeredová has been in a relationship with Italian businessman Alessandro Nasi.{{cite web|url=http://www.corrieredellosport.it/news/calcio/fuori-dal-campo/2015/12/22-6985060/alena_seredova_parla_di_buffon_sono_felice_se_lui_sta_bene/?cookieAccept|title=Alena Seredova parla di Buffon: "Sono felice se lui sta bene"|publisher=Il Corriere dello Sport|language=Italian|date=22 December 2015|accessdate=7 January 2016}} ==Filmography== * ''Ho visto le stelle ''(I Have Seen the Stars) (2003; ''Viděl jsem hvězdy''); comedy, running time: 91 minutes,
