revision.comment: /* Facilities */
revision.text:
The '''Anteater Recreation Center''' ('''ARC''') is an {{convert|89000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} indoor gym facility that is part of campus recreation at the [[University of California, Irvine]] (UCI); the anteater is the mascot of the [[UC Irvine Anteaters|UC Irvine athletics team]] (see [[University of California, Irvine#Athletics]] for the mascot's origin and history). It is open to all UCI students, faculty and staff members, alumni, and other university affiliates, including spouses.<ref>[http://www.campusrec.uci.edu/membership/index.asp UCI ARC Memberships]</ref>
The facility was designed by Langdon Wilson Architecture.<ref>Barbara Giasone, [http://www.ocregister.com/articles/center-123368-students-student.html "Students to get new rec center"], ''[[Orange County Register]]'', July 11, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://business.highbeam.com/4913/article-1G1-81109701/university-california-irvine-anteater-recreation-center "University of California -- Irvine, Anteater Recreation Center. (Post-Secondary Outstanding Buildings)."] ''American School & University'', November 1, 2001 {{subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}.</ref> It opened in January 2000, replacing older, cramped recreational facilities at the school's older gym, Crawford Hall. Built at a cost of $26 million, it was funded by a student referendum approved in May 1996, when UCI students voted to pay an additional $88 per quarter to fund the center and other athletic and recreational facilities.<ref>Jeff Gottlieb, [http://articles.latimes.com/2000/jan/24/local/me-57046 "Academic Exercise"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', January 24, 2000.</ref><ref>Paul McLeod, [http://articles.latimes.com/2000/sep/26/sports/sp-27042 "Irvine's Anteater Stadium Getting Ready for Bright New Look"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', September 26, 2000.</ref> The positive reception for the new center led students at other [[University of California]] campuses (such as [[UCLA]]) to push for similar improvements in their recreational facilities.<ref>Elizabeth Newman, [http://dailybruin.com/2002/07/21/students-declare-wooden-center/ "Students declare Wooden Center unfit"], ''[[Daily Bruin]]'', July 21, 2002.</ref>
The facility has been the setting for several [[Guinness World Records|Guinness world record]] events, including a 4,448-participant [[dodgeball]] game in 2011<ref>Andrew Blankstein, [http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2011/09/uc-irvine-sets-dodgeball-record.html "UC Irvine sets dodgeball world record"], ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', September 22, 2011.</ref> and a 3,875-combatant [[water pistol]] [[water fight|fight]] in 2013.<ref>Alanna Iliff, [http://www.ocregister.com/articles/irvine-527777-world-record.html "UCI water fight breaks Guinness World Record"], ''[[Orange County Register]]'', September 24, 2013.</ref>
==Facilities== ARC facilities<ref name="ARC">[http://www.campusrec.uci.edu/index.asp UCI ARC Facilities]</ref> include: * The main gym, which features three basketball or volleyball courts or nine [[badminton]] courts and utilizes hanging dividers to separate each court * A fitness lab, consisting of state of the art cardiovascular equipment, weight machines, and free-weights, as well as eight flat screen televisions * An indoor jogging track with a clock timer and rubber flooring * A 36’ high rock wall for beginning to advanced climbers * Three glass-enclosed [[racquetball]] courts * Five activity rooms for various fitness classes, clinics, and programs ** Physical Forum is the largest activity room and is home to group exercise classes, like Step, Pump N’ Sculpt, Aerobics, and [[Zumba]]. ** Sports Studio has matted flooring and can be used for [[martial arts]], wrestling, and stretching ** Activity Annex is the main facility for table tennis, fencing, and instructional dance classes ** Workout Shop is utilized by [[yoga]], [[kendo]], [[capoeira]], and [[belly dance]] classes ** Training Zone offers studio cycling, [[meditation]], and yoga classes. * A back court gym, a {{convert|7000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} gym with rounded corners, team dugouts, and inset goals, perfect for floor hockey and indoor soccer * A newly added Wellness Lab, geared towards functional training and featuring a Kinesis Wall and kinesis circuit machines, as well as cardio equipment and free weights and ten flat screen televisions * An aquatics plaza with a 25 meter by 25 meter lap pool * ARC fields, a {{convert|25|acre|m2|adj=on}} outdoor complex, for sports such as softball, soccer, football, rugby, lacrosse, basketball, roller hockey, and tennis * Exercise testing rooms, where various fitness tests, such as "Bod Pods" and "VO2 Submax Tests", are conducted * Massage therapy rooms with fully adjustable beds * A test kitchen and classroom that is used for demonstration and cooking classes * ARC Bar, offering fresh smoothies and light snacks
==Services== ARC services<ref name="ARC"/> include: * Classes and clinics that follow a non-credit, class format for learning or developing sports * Club sports directed to clubs centered on interest in one sport or fitness activity and involves competition among other collegiate club teams * Intramural sport leagues designed for student, faculty, and staff competition * Team Up and Odyssey High Ropes Course activities * Fitness and wellness programs designed to support participants' physical exercise and health goals * Certified personal training * Kinesis circuit training * Pilates reformer * Exercise testing * Massage * Outdoor adventures, including kayaking and paddle boarding, that provide an opportunity to overcome a psychological or physical challenge or barrier * Sailing * CPR/first aid classes * Gear Up, where ARC participants can check out equipment, including basketballs, racquets, and shower towels
==Intramural sports== * The ARC offers many intramural sports every quarter (fall, winter, spring, and summer) for all students, staff, and faculty, with an ARC membership, which are divided into leagues and tournaments. *Intramural sports are structured sport leagues and tournaments, which are designed for the everyday athlete. All activities are divided into different divisions of skill and competitiveness. * Fall quarter sports: arena soccer, flag football, volleyball, 3-on-3 basketball, coed basketball, tennis singles, 7 on 7 soccer, dodgeball, ultimate frisbee, and racquetball singles *Winter quarter sports: soccer, floor hockey, coed reverse volleyball, basketball, dodgeball, softball, wrestling, and track *Spring quarter sports: coed indoor soccer, coed volleyball, softball, "Call Your Own" basketball, racquetball singles, swim, bowling, and water polo *Summer quarter sports: softball, 4 on 4 coed volleyball, 3 on 3 basketball, 7 on 7 soccer, and kickball *In order to put in a team for intramural sports, one must pay a fee and make a roster complete with names, ID numbers, and three phone numbers and emails in case of rescheduling conflicts, etc. This can be done at the sales desk on the second floor of the ARC. *League games start in week 3 of the quarter and continue to week 7 or 8. *Playoffs begin in week 8 or 9 until week 10 or whenever necessary to finish the season. *League games take place on weekdays and some Sundays, and tournaments take place on weekdays to some Saturdays and Sundays. *Games are officiated by trained student officials.
==See also== * [[Student activities and traditions at UC Irvine]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.campusrec.uci.edu/ UCI Campus Recreation]

The club colours are yellow, blue and black and the home games are played at [[Budy stadium]], at [[Palace of Sport]] in Kharkiv and at "Saltivsky Lid" in Kharkiv.[http://ukrbandy.org.ua/clubs_en.html Ukrainian Bandy and Rinkbandy Federation: Clubs], read May 16, 2015 Avangard Budy won the [[list of Ukrainian bandy champions|Ukrainian championship]] in 2013. They also won the Ukrainian championship five times in the era of [[Ukrainian SSR]]. ==Sources== [[Category:Bandy clubs in Ukraine]] [[Category:Sport in Kharkiv]] [[Category:Bandy clubs in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Bandy clubs established in 1930]] {{Bandy-team-stub}} {{Ukraine-sport-stub}}

In baseball, a '''[[Captain (sports)|captain]]''' is an honorary title sometimes given to a member of the team to acknowledge his leadership. In the early days of baseball, a captain was a player who was responsible for many of the functions now assumed by [[Manager (baseball)|managers]] and [[Coach (baseball)|coaches]], such as preparing lineups, making decisions about strategy, and encouraging teamwork.<ref>{{cite book | last=Dickson | first=Paul | title=The New Dickson Baseball Dictionary | publisher=Mariner Books | year=1999 | page=101 | isbn=0-15-600580-8}}</ref> In amateur or youth baseball, a manager or coach may appoint a team captain to assist in communicating with the players and to encourage teamwork and improvement.<ref>{{cite book | author=ASEP | title=Coaching Baseball: Technical and Tactical Skills | publisher=Human Kinetics | year=2005 | page=240 | isbn=0-7360-4703-4}}</ref>
[[Major League Baseball]]'s official rules only briefly mention the position of team captain. Official Baseball Rule 4.03 Comment (formerly Rule 4.01 Comment) which discusses the submission of a team's lineup to the [[umpire (baseball)|umpire]], notes that obvious errors in the lineup should be brought to the attention of the team's manager or captain.<ref>{{citation | title=Official Baseball Rules | date=1949–2010 | publisher=Major League Baseball | page=32 | url=http://mlb.mlb.com/mlb/downloads/y2010/official_rules/2010_OfficialBaseballRules.pdf}}</ref>
In Major League Baseball, only a handful of teams have designated a player as captain in recent years, and there are no current team captains. [[Jerry Remy]], who was named as captain of the [[California Angels]] in 1977 at age 24, explains that in today's modern age of baseball, "there's probably no need for a captain on a major league team. I think there are guys who lead by example. You could name the best player on your team as captain, but he may not be the guy other players will talk to or who will quietly go to other players and give them a prod."<ref>{{cite book | last=Remy | first=Jerry |author2=Corey Sandler | title=Watching Baseball: Discovering the Game Within the Game | publisher=Globe Pequot | year=2006 | page=218}}</ref> They do not wear an [[National Hockey League|NHL]]-style "C" on their jersey. Retired first baseman [[Mike Sweeney]], former captain of the [[Kansas City Royals]] from 2003 to 2007, wore the "C" patch, as did two other recently retired captains: [[John Franco]] of the Mets, and [[Jason Varitek]] of the [[Boston Red Sox]].
==History== In the 19th and early 20th century, the captain held most of the on-field responsibilities that are held by managers and coaches in modern baseball. For example, according to the 1898 official rules, the captain was responsible for assigning the players' positions and batting order, for appealing to the umpire if he observed certain violations (for example, if the other team intentionally discolored the ball or its players illegally left the bench), and for informing the umpire of any special ground rules. During a period when teams didn't carry full-time coaches, the captain and one or more other players could serve as "coachers" of the base runners; the lines setting off the section where they were allowed to stand were designated as "captain's lines." If the umpire made a decision that could "be plainly shown by the code of rules to have been illegal", the "captain alone shall be allowed to make the appeal for reversal." The rules state that the captain must be one of the nine players, implying that a non-playing manager would not have been allowed to act in the captain's role. In contrast with modern baseball, the 1898 rules do not mention the managers having any rights to interact with the umpires. The rules allowed managers to sit on the team's bench during the game, but were otherwise silent with respect to rights and responsibilities of managers.<ref>{{cite book | last=Chadwick | first=Henry | title=Spalding's Official Base Ball Guide: 1898 | publisher=American Sports Publishing Company | year=1898 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uIdLAAAAYAAJ&dq=%22base%20ball%22%20captain%20manager&pg=PA167#v=onepage&q=%22base%20ball%22%20captain%20manager&f=false | pages=169–171, 175, 183}}</ref>
In early baseball, many teams had playing managers who had both the off-field responsibilities of managers and the on-field responsibilities of captains. They held the title of "manager-captain."<ref>For example, in 1902 the newspapers refer to "Captain-Manager [[John McGraw]] and [[Joe Kelley]]"; see {{cite news | title=M'Graw at Polo Grounds: Six of the New York Baseball Team Are Released | newspaper=[[The New York Times]] | date=July 18, 1902 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1902/07/18/117979853.pdf }} and {{cite news | title=Yesterday's Baseball Games: New York and Cincinnati Teams Each Win a Game at the Polo Grounds—Brooklyn Won | newspaper=The New York Times | date=August 14, 1902 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1902/08/14/101962901.pdf }}</ref> In contrast, teams that had non-playing managers hired a player to serve as captain. For example, in early 1902 [[Jack Doyle (baseball)|Jack Doyle]] was signed as captain and first baseman of the [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] while non-player [[Horace Fogel]] was manager.<ref>{{cite news | title=Doyle Signed by New York: Famous Baseball Player to Captain the Team and Play First Base—Pleased with the Club's Outlook | newspaper=The New York Times | date=February 27, 1902 | url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1902/02/27/101939155.pdf }}</ref>
Though the role of a captain has been significant in the histories of teams such as the [[New York Yankees]], the [[Boston Red Sox]], and the [[San Francisco Giants]], other teams, such as the [[Milwaukee Brewers]], have, as of 2016, never had a captain.

{{Infobox football biography | name = Christy Bonevacia | fullname = Christy Bonevacia | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1985|12|25}} | birth_place = [[Willemstad, Curaçao]], [[Netherlands Antilles]] | height = | position = [[Midfielder]] | currentclub = [[VVA '71]] | clubnumber = | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = [[AZ (football club)|AZ]] | years1 = 2003–2005 | years2 = 2005–2007 | years3 = 2008 | years4 = 2008–2011 | years5 = 2011–2012 | years6 = 2012– | clubs1 = [[AZ (football club)|AZ]] | clubs2 = [[FC Emmen]] | clubs3 = [[HFC Haarlem]] | clubs4 = [[SV Spakenburg]] | clubs5 = [[Zwaluwen '30]] | clubs6 = [[VVA '71]] | caps1 = 1 | caps2 = 80 | caps3 = 13 | caps4 = 16 | caps5 = | caps6 = | goals1 = 0 | goals2 = 0 | goals3 = 0 | goals4 = 0 | goals5 = 0 | goals6 = | nationalyears1 = 2011– | nationalteam1 = [[Curaçao national football team|Curaçao]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | pcupdate = | ntupdate = }}
'''Christy Bonevacia''' (born 25 December 1985 in [[Willemstad, Curaçao]] in the former [[Netherlands Antilles]]) is a [[Curaçao]] [[Football (soccer)|footballer]] who currently plays for Dutch amateur side [[VVA '71]].
==Club career== Bonevacia came through the youth ranks at [[AZ (football club)|AZ]] and in 2005, he played for AZ in the [[UEFA Cup]] semi-final against [[Sporting Portugal]]. He then played for [[Eerste Divisie]] sides Emmen and Haarlem before moving to Spakenburg.
==Personal life== He works for a security company.
==External links== *{{nl icon}} [http://www.vi.nl/Spelers/Speler/ChristyBonevacia.htm Profile at VI] *{{nl icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110716114316/http://www.spakenburg.com/site/?christybonevacia Player profile] - SV Spakenburg

{{Infobox chess opening |openingname = Closed Game |image = {{Chess diagram | | |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd|nd|rd |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|pd|pd | | | | | | | | | | | |pd| | | | | | | |pl| | | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl|pl| |pl|pl|pl|pl |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl | }} |moves=1.d4 d5 |ECO=D00-D69 |birth= |nameorigin = |parentopening = [[Queen's Pawn Game]] |AKA= Double Queen's Pawn Opening
Double Queen's Pawn Game |chessgid=75972&move=2&moves=d4.d5 }} A '''Closed Game''' (or '''Double Queen's Pawn Opening''') is a [[chess opening]] that begins with the moves: :1. [[b:Chess Opening Theory/1. d4|d4]] [[b:Chess Opening Theory/1. d4/1...d5|d5]] The move 1.d4 offers the same benefits to development and center control as does 1.e4, but unlike with the [[King's Pawn Game|King Pawn openings]] where the e4 pawn is undefended after the first move, the d4 pawn is protected by White's queen. This slight difference has a tremendous effect on the opening. For instance, whereas the [[King's Gambit]] is rarely played today at the highest levels of chess, the [[Queen's Gambit]] remains popular at all levels of play. Also, compared with the King Pawn openings, [[transposition (chess)|transpositions]] between variations are more common and important in the closed games. {{algebraic notation|pos=tocleft}} {{clear}} ==Specific openings== {{Chess diagram small | tright | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | | |pl| | | | | | |pl|bl|pl|nl| | |pl|pl| |nl| |pl|pl|pl |rl| |bl|ql|rl| |kl| | White's formation in the Colle system }} The [[Richter-Veresov Attack]], [[Colle System]], [[Stonewall Attack]], [[Torre Attack]], [[London System]], and [[Blackmar-Diemer Gambit]] are classified as [[Queen's Pawn Game]]s because White plays d4 but not c4. The Richter-Veresov is rarely played at the top levels of chess. The Colle and Stonewall are both ''Systems'', rather than specific opening variations. White develops aiming for a particular formation without great concern over how Black chooses to defend. Both these systems are popular with club players because they are easy to learn, but are rarely used by professionals because a well prepared opponent playing Black can equalize fairly easily. The Blackmar-Diemer Gambit is an attempt by White to open lines and obtain attacking chances. Most professionals consider it too risky for serious games, but it is popular with amateurs and in [[blitz chess]]. {{clear}} {{Chess diagram small |tright | |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd|nd|rd |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|pd|pd | | | | | | | | | | | |pd| | | | | | |pl|pl| | | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|pl |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl |Queen's Gambit after 2.c4 }} The most important closed openings are in the [[Queen's Gambit]] family (White plays 2.c4). The Queen's Gambit is somewhat misnamed, since White can always regain the offered pawn if desired. In the [[Queen's Gambit Accepted]], Black plays ...dxc4, giving up the center for free development and the chance to try to give White an isolated queen pawn with a subsequent ...c5 and ...cxd4. White will get active pieces and possibilities for the attack. Black has two popular ways to decline the pawn, the [[Slav Defense|Slav]] (2...c6) and the [[Queen's Gambit Declined]] (2...e6). Both of these moves lead to an immense forest of variations that can require a great deal of opening study to play well. Among the many possibilities in the Queen's Gambit Declined are the [[Queen's Gambit Declined, Mainline Orthodox Defense|Orthodox Defense]], [[Lasker Defense]], the [[Cambridge Springs Defense]], the [[Tartakower Variation]], and the [[Tarrasch Defense|Tarrasch and Semi-Tarrasch Defenses]]. {{clear}} {{Chess diagram small |tright | |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd|nd|rd |pd|pd|pd| | |pd|pd|pd | | | | | | | | | | | |pd|pd| | | | | |pl|pl| | | | | | | | | | | | |pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|pl |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl |Albin countergambit after 2...e5 }} Black replies to the Queen's Gambit other than 2...dxc4, 2...c6, and 2...e6 are uncommon. The [[Chigorin Defense]] (2...Nc6) is playable but rare. The [[Symmetrical Defense]] (2...c5) is the most direct challenge to [[Queen's Gambit]] theory — Can Black equalize by simply copying White's moves? Most opening theoreticians believe not, and consequently the Symmetrical Defense is not popular. The [[Baltic Defense]] (2...Bf5) takes the most direct solution to solving the problem of Black's queen bishop by developing it on the second move. Although it is not trusted by most elite players, it has not been refuted and some very strong grandmasters have played it. The [[Albin Countergambit]] (2...e5) is generally considered too risky for top-level tournament play. Similarly, the [[Marshall Defense]] (2...Nf6) is very rarely seen in grandmaster play, as most theoreticians consider it definitely inferior for Black. {{clear}} ==List== * 1.d4 d5 Double Queen's Pawn Opening or Closed Game * 1.d4 d5 2.Nc3 Nf6 3.Bg5 [[Richter-Veresov Attack]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 [[Queen's Gambit]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 dxc4 [[Queen's Gambit Accepted]] (QGA) * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 c5 [[Symmetrical Defense]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 c6 [[Slav Defense]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 Nc6 [[Chigorin Defense]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e5 [[Albin Countergambit]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 e6 [[Queen's Gambit Declined]] (QGD) * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 Bf5 [[Baltic Defense]] * 1.d4 d5 2.c4 Nf6 [[Marshall Defense]] * 1.d4 d5 2.e3 [[Stonewall Attack]] * 1.d4 d5 2.e4 [[Blackmar-Diemer Gambit]] * 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 Nf6 3.e3 [[Colle System]] * 1.d4 d5 2.Bf4 [[London System]] * 1.d4 d5 2.Nf3 f5 ==See also== *[[Open Game]] (1.e4 e5) *[[Semi-Open Game]] (1.e4 moves other than 1...e5) *[[Semi-Closed Game]] (1.d4 moves other than 1...d5) *[[Flank opening]] (1.c4, 1.Nf3, 1.f4, and others) *[[Irregular chess opening]] ==References== {{wikibooks|Chess Opening Theory|1. d4/1...d5|Closed Game}} {{reflist}} * {{citation | last=De Firmian | first=Nick | authorlink=Nick de Firmian | title=[[Modern Chess Openings]]: MCO-14 | publisher=Random House Puzzles & Games | year=1999 | isbn=0-8129-3084-3}} [[Category:Chess openings|*Closed Game]] [[Category:Chess terminology]]

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=December 2015}}
The '''Columbia Country Club''', located in [[Chevy Chase, Maryland|Chevy Chase]], [[Maryland]], is the successor of the Columbia Golf Club, which was organized on September 29, 1898<ref name=Shapiro>{{cite book | last = Shapiro | first = Len | title = The Great Book of Washington DC Sports Lists | publisher = Running Press | location = New York | year = 2008 | isbn = 0786741708 | page=257 }}</ref> by nine men. Originally there were twenty members. The golf course, which opened in 1911, was designed by [[Herbert Barker (golfer)|Herbert Barker]].<ref name=Shapiro/><ref name="Herbert Barker design">{{cite web|title=Club History|url=http://www.columbiacc.org/Default.aspx?p=DynamicModule&pageid=397118&ssid=319837&vnf=1|website=ColumbiaCC.org|accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref> The first location of the Club was on the east side of Brightwood Avenue, afterwards known as Georgia Avenue, in the neighborhood of Schuetzen Park. It stands as one of the oldest and most prestigious country clubs in the [[United States]]. Through its history, the club has counted among its members two Five Star Generals, [[Omar Bradley]] and [[Hap Arnold]], along with countless politicians, most notably [[Barack Obama]], journalists, CEOs and lobbyists.
==History== The present site on Connecticut Avenue was purchased in 1909 from the Chevy Chase Land Company. The certificate of incorporation is dated August 25, 1909. The design of Frederick B. Pyle for the club house was selected from among four submitted. The golf course, completed in 1911, was designed by [[Herbert Barker (golfer)|Herbert Barker]], a noted golfer and course architect of the day.<ref name="Herbert Barker design" /> [[Walter Travis]] made extensive renovations to the course in 1915.<ref name=Homsey>{{cite web|last1=Homsey|first1=Dave|title=The Walter J. Travis Society: 5th hole at Columbia Country Club / Chevy Chase, MD|url=http://travissociety.com/who-was-travis/golf-course-architect/travis-bunkers/columbia_5th/|website=TravisSociety.com|date=21 August 2011|accessdate=18 December 2015}}</ref> Although there is no newspaper record of the event, the opening of the new Club occurred on January 6, 1911. Early Club minutes were lost. The course was one of the favorite courses of President [[Woodrow Wilson]].
The [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] was held at the Club in 1921, won by Englishman, [[Jim Barnes]].<ref name=Shapiro/> President [[Warren Harding]] presented the Champion's Trophy.<ref>{{cite book | last = Sommers | first = Robert | title = Golf anecdotes : from the links of Scotland to Tiger Woods | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | year = 2004 | isbn = 0195172655 | page =111 }}</ref> With the exception of the eighth hole, there have been changes (for the better) on all holes of the course. Several acres were added to the original {{convert|126|acre|ha}} in the 1930s. Other improvements, such as new tee boxes and a better irrigation system, were added in the early part of 2012.
The first swimming pool (donated by Donald Woodward) opened in 1925. The Olympic-sized pool was built much later and the entire area was totally renovated in 1978. A profusion of tennis courts have existed from the beginning of the Club. Platform tennis courts were added in the 1960s. Major changes have been made on the 15th, 16th and 17th holes of the golf course, made possible by the construction of a water line through the area by the WSSC under its power of eminent domain. In addition, 2009 saw the completion of a major renovation and addition of the club house, adding an indoor swimming facility, upgraded fitness center, new bowling alley (duckpin), locker rooms, ice skating rink (winter only) and additional parking among other things. Throughout its rich history, only three head golf professionals ever worked at the club, [[Fred McLeod]], William Strasbaugh, and Robert Dolan (its current head PGA Professional).
Columbia has a history of counting some of the best amateur golfers in the [[Washington, D.C.]] metropolitan area among its membership. Martin R. West III, a multiple club champion at Columbia, made the cut in 1973 the [[Masters Tournament]] and 1976 [[U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]]; he has competed in 19 United States Amateurs, is a former US [[Walker Cup]] team member, and has won numerous area tournaments including nine Maryland Amateurs. The annual club championship, contested in early September, is one of the most prestigious in the DC area. Columbia's MSGA A team has been very successful, winning the competition multiple times (most recently 2017).
[[Christine Blasey Ford]] testified to the US Senate on September 27, 2018<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/27/us/politics/kavanaugh-hearings-dr-ford.html?action=click&module=Spotlight&pgtype=Homepage|title=Kavanaugh Testimony Updates: ‘You Have Replaced Advice and Consent With Search and Destroy’|access-date=2018-09-27|language=en}}</ref>, that she was likely at the club prior to attending the social gathering at which she was allegedly sexually assaulted by [[Judge Brett Kavanaugh]].
==The course==
The Columbia course favors shotmaking and finesse over the ability to drive the ball long distances. The natural topography of the area means that Columbia's course is very hilly, with tight fairways and small, undulating greens that are almost universally sloped back to front. Course superintendents generally keep the Columbia greens at a very high speed, and rarely do they roll anything less than an 11 on the [[Stimpmeter|Stimp meter]].
A common saying among members and caddies is that "there are only two flat lies at Columbia, on the tee and in your pocket". Because of the layout, driving the ball long distances can often get a player into trouble due to deep rough, side-hill lies, pot bunkers, and the aforementioned tight fairways. Almost every approach shot on the golf course plays significantly either uphill or downhill, including severe downhill plays on #2, #5, #12, #14, #15, and #16. Hole #17 at Columbia is a truly unique hole, with only a 200-yard tee shot required to a short but wide section of fairway. From there, the player must chip straight uphill only 70 yards to a green sloped from front to back.
The [[signature hole]], however, remains the par 3 16th, which, legend has it, served as [[Bobby Jones (golfer)|Bobby Jones]]'s inspiration for the 12th hole at [[Augusta National Golf Club]]. From one of three tee boxes, the hole plays to a very long, narrow green with three distinct levels that is guarded completely along the front by a large pond. Complicating matters are two pot bunkers, one in front of the green and one behind. The hole has been consistently rated among the best in the area, and was ranked by ''[[Washingtonian (magazine)|Washingtonian]]'' magazine locally.
Overall, the par 70 (35-35) course measures {{convert|6900|yd}} in length, with a course rating of 72.3 and slope rating of 139.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.columbiacc.org Columbia Country Club official site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080723105906/http://www.townofchevychase.org/assets/documents/pdfs/history/20.pdf Official Town of Chevy Chase History] * [http://washingtonexaminer.com/in-the-tiger-era-columbia-country-club-still-holds-up/article/93286 August 2009 Washington Examiner Article about the golf course]

'''Right Field:''' {{convert|330|ft|m|sp=us}} ([[Baseball]]) | acreage = | tenants = [[Creighton Bluejays baseball]] and [[College softball|softball]] }} The '''Creighton Sports Complex''' is a [[baseball]] and [[softball]] venue located on the campus of [[Creighton University]] in [[Omaha, Nebraska]], United States. It is home to the [[College softball|softball]] team, members of the [[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Big East Conference (2013–present)|Big East Conference]], and former home of the Creighton University baseball team. The baseball team moved to [[TD Ameritrade Park Omaha]] in 2011. The facility opened in 1988[http://www.gocreighton.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=1000&ATCLID=1150415 Creighton Sports Complex] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091217193509/http://www.gocreighton.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=1000&ATCLID=1150415 |date=2009-12-17 }} at gocreighton.com, URL accessed December 23, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5mEdYHaBk?url=http://www.gocreighton.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID%3D1000%26ATCLID%3D1150415 Archived] 12/23/09 and has a capacity of 2,000 at the baseball diamond[http://www.und.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/99ncaa-creighton.html Creighton Bluejays] at und.com, URL accessed December 23, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5mEdcpzau?url=http://www.und.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/99ncaa-creighton.html Archived] 12/23/09 and 1,000 at the softball diamond.[http://www.gocreighton.com/fls/1000/mediaguide/softball/Pages1-6.pdf?DB_OEM_ID=1000 2004 Creighton Softball] at gocreighton.com, URL accessed December 23, 2009. [https://www.webcitation.org/5mEdhajsn?url=http://www.gocreighton.com/fls/1000/mediaguide/softball/Pages1-6.pdf?DB_OEM_ID%3D1000 Archived] 12/23/09 Both fields are surfaced with [[synthetic turf]]. ==Layout== The facility contains both a [[baseball]] and [[softball]] diamond. A photo of the facility is available [http://www.gocreighton.com//share/ViewPhoto.dbml?ATCLPID=&ATCLID=1150415&DB_MENU_ID=&SPSID=93887&SPID=78&IN_SUBSCRIBER_CONTENT=&DB_OEM_ID=1000&LOAD_IMAGE_ID=672956&LOAD_IMAGE_SIZE=400 here]. Also part of the facility is the [[Kitty Gaughan Pavilion]], which contains offices and indoor training areas for both sports, as well as additional facilities for other Creighton sports. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Big East Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Nebraska NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Nebraska]] [[Category:Sports venues in Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:Creighton Bluejays baseball]] [[Category:1998 establishments in Nebraska]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1998]] [[Category:College softball venues in the United States]] {{Nebraska-baseball-venue-stub}}

(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|55000000|1995}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Odell Associates | project_manager = | structural engineer = Fleming and Associates, PA | services engineer = | general_contractor = [[Turner Construction]] | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 10,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[Fayetteville Force]] ([[Central Hockey League|CHL]]) (1997–2001)
[[Fayetteville Patriots]] ([[NBDL]]) (2001–2006)
[[Fayetteville Marksmen]] ([[SPHL]]) (2002–present)
[[Cape Fear Wildcats]] ([[af2]]) (2002–2004)

[[Fayetteville Force (SIFL)|Fayetteville Force]] ([[Southern Indoor Football League|SIFL]]) (2011)
[[Cape Fear Heroes]] ([[American Indoor Football|AIF]]/[[X-League Indoor Football|XLIF]]/[[Supreme Indoor Football|SIF]]/[[American Arena League|AAL]]) (2012–2015, 2017–present) | embedded = | website = {{URL|http://crowncomplexnc.com/coliseum/|Venue Website}} | publictransit = }} The '''Crown Coliseum'''{{cite web |url=http://www.fayobserver.com/news/local/crown-complex-shows-off-its-changes/article_fe553fe3-7815-5547-8de9-c9f708225956.html |title=Crown Complex shows off its changes |last1=Campbell |first1=Sarah |last2= |first2= |date=March 27, 2014 |website=[[The Fayetteville Observer]] |publisher=Fayetteville Publishing Company |access-date=November 26, 2015}} (originally the '''Cumberland County Crown Coliseum''') is a multi-purpose arena in [[Fayetteville, North Carolina]], that broke ground in 1995{{cite news |title=Coliseum Still Lacks 'Crowning' Touch|first=Gary|last=Moss|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=FV&p_theme=fv&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0F54F8CEDC91DF91&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|newspaper=[[Fayetteville Observer]]|date=March 23, 1995|accessdate=November 19, 2011}} and opened in 1997.{{cite news |title=Lights Come On at New Crown Coliseum|url=http://www.wral.com/news/local/story/166506/|work=WRAL|date=October 23, 1997|accessdate=November 19, 2011}} It is currently home to the [[Fayetteville Marksmen]] [[ice hockey]] team and the [[Cape Fear Heroes]] [[indoor American football|indoor football]] team. During the early stages of its construction, Fayetteville’s Crown Coliseum was mentioned as a possible temporary home for the [[National Hockey League|NHL’s]] [[Carolina Hurricanes]], but this was blocked by minor-league hockey executive [[Bill Coffey]] who had signed an exclusive lease agreement with the arena for the [[Fayetteville Force]] of the [[Central Hockey League]].{{cite book|first=Jon C.|last=Scott|title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South|year=2006|publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.|page=103|isbn=1-894974-21-2}} It was reported in mid January that [[TNA Wrestling]] would be taping its weekly [[TNA iMPACT!]] broadcast in the arena on February 24, 2011—which would be only the second time in its history that the show would be broadcast outside Universal Studio's iMPACT! zone in Orlando, Florida. [[WWE]] taped its annual [[WWE Tribute to the Troops|Tribute to the Troops]] show at the venue on December 11, 2011. Fayetteville native, rapper [[J. Cole]]'s [[Forest Hills Drive: Live]] and his [[concert film]], ''Forest Hills Drive: Homecoming'' was recorded at the arena on August 30, 2015, during his [[Forest Hills Drive Tour]].{{cite web|last1=Boehrer|first1=Kat|title=Here's J. Cole's ‘Forest Hills Drive Live' Album|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2016/01/j-cole-releases-live-album-on-his-birthday|website=Complex|accessdate=21 November 2016|date=January 27, 2016}} ''Forest Hills Drive: Homecoming'' aired on [[HBO]], January 9, 2016.{{cite web|last1=Montes|first1=Patrick|title=J. Cole's 90-Minute HBO Documentary 'Forest Hills Drive: Homecoming' Is Here|url=https://hypebeast.com/2016/1/j-coles-90-minute-hbo-documentary-forest-hills-drive-homecoming-is-here|website=hypebeast|accessdate=21 November 2016|date=January 10, 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Commons category-inline|Cumberland County Crown Coliseum}} ==External links== * [http://crowncomplexnc.com/ Crown Coliseum] {{coord|35.015124|-78.891714|region:US_type:landmark|display=title}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the

revision.comment: From 1896 until 1990 would be 94 years.
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} [[File:Fellows Park - Geograph-2008825.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Fellows Park in 1982]] '''Fellows Park''' was a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Walsall]], [[England]]. It was the home ground of [[Walsall F.C.]] from 1896 until 1990, when the team moved to the [[Bescot Stadium]].
Fellows Park was situated about a quarter of a mile away from the club's present ground, The Bescot Stadium, at the junction of Hilary Street and Wallows Lane.
The club moved to the ground from [[West Bromwich Road]] in 1896. Until 1930 it was named '''Hilary Street''', at which point it was renamed after H.L. Fellows, a club director. Walsall's record home attendance was at Fellows Park, when 25,453 spectators were present for the team's Second Division match against [[Newcastle United]] on 29 August 1961.<ref name=FGG>{{cite web |url=http://www.footballgroundguide.com/old-grounds-and-stands/fellows_park_walsall.htm |title=Fellows Park Walsall Football Club |work=Football Ground Guide |access-date=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
By March 1988, the club was planning to build a new stadium at nearby Bescot Crescent.<ref name=Twohundredpercent>{{cite web |url=http://twohundredpercent.net/those-we-have-lost-fellows-park-walsall-fc/ |title=Those We Have Lost: Fellows Park, Walsall FC |date=Jun 29, 2011 |publisher=Twohundredpercent |access-date=September 5, 2017}}</ref> Within two years, construction work was underway at the new stadium site and the last league game at Fellows Park was played on 1 May 1990, when Walsall, in the process of their second successive relegation which took them into the [[Football League Fourth Division]], drew 1–1 at home to [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]], with [[Andy Dornan]] scoring the last league goal at the ground – his only goal in his time at Walsall.<ref name=ExpressAndStar>{{cite web |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/walsall-fc/2015/05/11/walsall-hero-recalls-fellows-park-25-years-on/ |title=Walsall hero on Fellows Park 25 years later |date=May 11, 2015 |work=[[Express & Star]] |publisher=[[MNA Media]] |access-date=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
The final game played at the ground was on 11 May 1990, when retiring defender [[Peter Hart (footballer)|Peter Hart's]] testimonial was held there with local rivals [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] providing the opposition. This game also ended in a 1–1 draw, with [[Gary Shaw]] scoring an equaliser for Walsall in the 37th minute, thus going down in history as the last player to score at the stadium, in its 94-year history.<ref name=ExpressAndStar/> The new [[Bescot Stadium]] was ready for the [[1990–91 in English football|1990–91 season]].<ref name=ExpressAndStar2>{{cite web |url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/2015/08/18/25-years-at-bescot-the-stadium-that-changed-clubs-fortunes/ |title=25 years at Bescot: The stadium that changed Walsall's fortunes |date=May 11, 2015 |work=[[Express & Star]] |publisher=[[MNA Media]] |access-date=September 5, 2017}}</ref> A reminder of Fellows Park remains in the new stadium, in the name of the H.L. Fellows Stand.<ref name=FourFourTwo/> The old stadium was demolished soon after its closure and a [[Morrisons]] supermarket built on the site.<ref name=FourFourTwo>{{cite web |url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/memoriam-10-englands-beloved-long-lost-grounds?page=0%2C1 |title=In memoriam: 10 of England's beloved, long-lost grounds |date=November 11, 2015 |work=[[FourFourTwo]] |publisher=[[Haymarket Media Group|Haymarket]] |access-date=September 5, 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox organization | name = Football Foundation | logo = File:Foundationlogo.png | founded = 2000 | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Lord Pendry]]<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sthelensstar.co.uk/news/15350715.Junior_Football_Club_to_kick_off_new_home_with_official_opening_this_Saturday/ |title=Junior Football Club to kick off new home with official opening this Saturday |last=Maxwell |first=Kelsey |date=2017-06-16 |publisher=[[St Helens Star]] |access-date=2017-06-19}}</ref> | leader_title2 = Chairman | leader_name2 = Gary Hoffman | leader_title3 = CEO | leader_name3 = Paul Thorogood | leader_title4 = Funding Partners | leader_name4 = [[Premier League]], [[The FA]] and the Government (via [[Sport England]]). | website = {{URL|footballfoundation.org.uk}} }} The '''Football Foundation''' is the [[United Kingdom]]’s largest sports charity, channelling funding from the [[Premier League]], [[The FA]] and the Government (via [[Sport England]]) into transforming the landscape of grassroots sport in England. <ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.henleystandard.co.uk/news/rotherfield-united/111105/football-club-plans-to-grow-in-time-for-50th-year.html |title=Football club plans to grow in time for 50th year |date=2017-06-12 |publisher=[[Henley Standard]] |access-date=2017-06-19}}</ref>
==History==
Launched in 2000, the Football Foundation awards grants to grassroots clubs and organisations to help build and refurbish new and existing community sports facilities, such as changing pavilions, natural grass pitches or all-weather playing surfaces, for schools, and local authority facilities or sports clubs.
Since 2000, the Foundation has awarded 17,000 grants worth more than £615m towards improving grassroots sport, which it has used to attract additional partnership funding of over £817m – over £1.4bn of investment into the grassroots game. The Foundation’s grassroots facilities investment has helped to develop:
- 1,006 changing facilities
- 2,921 real grass pitches
- 702 artificial grass pitches
- 101 multi-use games areas.
The Foundation also delivers large-scale sport CSR programmes, including the Mayor of London: Sport Facilities Fund, on behalf of Mayor Sadiq Khan, as well as the multi-award winning Barclays Spaces for Sports programme that has created 200 new or refurbished community sports sites across England.
Moreover, the Foundation is the delivery partner for a number of Premier League and FA community schemes, including the Premier League Kit and Equipment scheme, and The FA’s Grow the Game and Respect schemes.
== Ambassadors ==
* [[Peter Beardsley|Peter Beardsley MBE]] * [[Georgie Bingham]] * [[Dion Dublin]] * [[Graeme Le Saux]] * [[Gary Neville]] * [[John Scales]] * [[Ben Shephard]] * [[Gareth Southgate]] * [[Graham Taylor|Graham Taylor OBE]] * [[Dan Walker (broadcaster)|Dan Walker]] * [[Faye White]] * [[Lawrie McMenemy]] * [[Nigel Adkins]] * [[James Beattie (footballer)|James Beattie]] * [[Chris Powell]] * [[Hayley McQueen]] * [[Duncan Watmore]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = FoxSports.com | logo = | logo_size = 200px | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://www.foxsports.com/ www.foxsports.com] | commercial = | type = [[Sports]] | registration = | owner = [[Fox Entertainment Group]]
([[21st Century Fox]]) | developer = | operating_system = | launch date = {{start date and age|2001|7}} | current status = Public | revenue = | alexa = {{Decrease}} 2,284 ({{as of|2017|6|28|alt=June 2017}}){{cite web|url=http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/foxsports.com |title=Foxsports.com Site Info |publisher=[[Alexa Internet]] |accessdate=28 June 2017}} }} '''FoxSports.com''' is a [[sports news]] website operated by the [[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]] division of [[Fox Entertainment Group]]. The website primarily features streaming video content surrounding sports-related topics, including segments and features from the division's studio programming. == History == In May 2004, Fox Sports entered into an agreement with [[Microsoft]] for FoxSports.com to become the official sports portal of [[MSN.com]], replacing [[ESPN.com]]; the deal included joint advertising sales and revenue sharing, and integration of FoxSports.com into MSN.com and its associated services.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/game-on-for-msn-foxsports-site/|title=Game on for MSN, FoxSports site|work=CNET|access-date=2017-06-27|language=en}} The partnership was dissolved in 2014. In 2016, Fox Sports executive Jamie Horowitz took over the operations of the division's digital properties. Horowitz (who had led the [[Fox Sports 1]] cable channel's shift to opinion-based studio programming rather than general sports news coverage) began to institute new editorial practices at FoxSports.com, proposing that the website's written content be used to promote Fox Sports pundits and their television programs, including Fox Sports 1 hosts [[Colin Cowherd]] and [[Skip Bayless]], rather than original reports. During the lead-up to [[Super Bowl LI]], the website piloted an aspect of this content strategy by having articles [[ghostwriting|ghostwritten]] under the names of FS1 pundits.{{Cite news|url=http://awfulannouncing.com/fox/jamie-horowitz-fox-sports-digital.html|title=Frustration, uncertainty, dread and layoffs: An inside look at Jamie Horowitz's takeover of Fox Sports Digital|date=2017-06-27|work=Awful Announcing|access-date=2017-06-28|language=en-US}} On June 26, 2017, Fox Sports redesigned its website to focus primarily on streaming video content only, rather than written articles. At the same time, Fox Sports laid off 20 writers so these positions could be filled by video-focused roles.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-06-26/fox-sports-cuts-web-writing-staff-to-invest-more-in-online-video|title=Fox Sports Cuts Web Writing Staff to Invest More in Online Video|date=2017-06-26|work=Bloomberg|access-date=2017-06-27}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/fox-sports-job-cuts-writing-video-katie-nolan-20170626.html|title=Latest Fox Sports shake-up eliminates writing jobs|work=Philly.com|access-date=2017-06-27}} The video content draws largely from FS1 studio programs. On July 3, 2017, Horowitz was fired from Fox Sports over allegations of sexual harassment.{{cite web|title=Jamie Horowitz Fired at Fox Sports Amid Harassment Probe|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/jamie-horowitz-exiting-fox-sports-1018505|website=The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate=3 July 2017}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==See also== {{Portal|Journalism}} *[[Fox Sports Go]] ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.foxsports.com/}} {{Fox Sports}} {{Fox Entertainment Group}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Foxsports.Com}} [[Category:Sport websites]]

revision.comment: short description added
revision.text:
{{short description|sports data and technology company}} '''Genius Sports''' is a sports data and technology company that provides data management and integrity services to major sports leagues and organizations.
The company was formed in 2016 following a merger between Betgenius, a technology and data supplier to the betting industry, and SportingPulse International, a sports data and software business, to form Genius Sports Group.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/darrenheitner/2016/04/19/is-major-league-baseball-ready-to-embrace-sports-betting/|title=Is Major League Baseball Ready To Embrace Sports Betting?|last=Heitner|first=Darren|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref>
Betgenius became a subsidiary of Genius Sports Group with its co-founder Mark Locke becoming the Group CEO.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://leadersinsport.com/news/leaders-40-awards-class-2017/|title=Leaders Under 40 Awards Class of 2017 Announced|website=Leaders|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sbcnews.co.uk/retail/2016/04/19/29889/|title=Genius Sports Officially Launches Following Merger|last1=Massey|first1=Luke|website=SBC News|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref>
In 2017, Genius Sports acquired Data Project, a volleyball technology provider. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://quoi.co.uk/volleyball-technology-specialist-acquired-by-genius-sports/|title=Volleyball Technology Specialist Acquired by Genius Sports|website=Quoi|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://quoi.co.uk/volleyball-technology-specialist-acquired-by-genius-sports/|title=Volleyball Technology Specialist Acquired by Genius Sports – Quoi|website=quoi.co.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2018-08-10}}</ref>
In July 2018, Genius Sports Group was acquired by [[Apax Partners]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-07-30/sports-data-company-genius-sold-to-private-equity-apax-partners|title=Sports Data Company Genius Sold to Private Equity Apax Partners|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportindustry.biz/news/genius-sports-group-acquired|title=Genius Sports Group acquired|date=2018-07-31|work=www.sportindustry.biz|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref>
== Operations ==
Genius Sports provides software solutions to sports leagues and federations. This technology enables sports to capture, manage and distribute their data and statistics and is used by basketball leagues globally.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/02/sports/sports-betting.html|title=When Sports Betting Is Legal, the Value of Game Data Soars|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportbusiness.com/sport-news/fiba-extends-genius-sports-partnership|title=Fiba extends Genius Sports partnership|date=2016-04-25|work=SportBusiness Group|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref>
In September 2017, the [[PGA Tour]] launched a new Integrity Program to "maintain integrity and prevent mitigate betting-related corruption in [[PGA Tour]] competitions."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.golf.com/tour-news/2017/09/19/tour-launch-integrity-program-combat-gambling-issues|title=PGA Tour to launch Integrity Program to 'protect' tournaments from gambling issues|last1=Dethier|first1=Dylan|website=GOLF|accessdate=13 July 2018}}</ref> Genius Sports was selected to support the [[PGA Tour]] through bet monitoring and educational services.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-golf-pga-gambling/pga-tour-hires-london-firm-to-monitor-betting-activity-idUKKCN1BT2MR|title=PGA Tour hires London firm to monitor betting activity|website=Reuters|accessdate=11 July 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://eu.usatoday.com/story/sports/golf/2018/04/11/pga-tour-supports-legalized-sports-betting-reasons-may-surprise-you/506874002/|title=PGA Tour supports legalized sports betting and its reasons may surprise you|work=USA TODAY|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref>
In November 2018, [[Football DataCo]], the rights holder of all the professional football leagues in England and Scotland, announced its new integrity strategy alongside Genius Sports and [[Perform Group]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.igamingbusiness.com/news/football-dataco-pens-integrity-deal-genius-perform|title=Football DataCo pens integrity deal with Genius, Perform|website=iGaming Business|accessdate=11 July 2018}}</ref> This agreement marked the first time two technology companies had combined to help protect a sport against match-fixing.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/football-notebook-everton-must-pay-3-5m-release-clause-to-hire-dyche-32t780t9d|title=Football Notebook: Everton must pay £3.5m release clause to hire Dyche|last=Correspondent|first=Matt Hughes, Deputy Football|date=2017-11-11|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en|issn=0140-0460}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.sportindustry.biz/news/genius-sports-joins-perform-unveil-integrity-strategy|title=Genius Sports joins Perform to unveil integrity strategy|date=2017-11-14|work=www.sportindustry.biz|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref>
In May 2018, the [[National Collegiate Athletics Association]] (NCAA) announced a landmark new statistics initiative for its 1,100 Members alongside Genius Sports. The deal aimed to modernise how NCAA Schools and Conferences harness game statistics to engage fans, drive performance levels and manage their operations. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/chalk/story/_/id/23502387/sports-betting-ncaa-announces-10-year-data-partnership-genius-sports|title=NCAA announces 10-year data partnership with Genius Sports|last1=Purdum|first1=David|website=ESPN|accessdate=10 July 2018}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-05-14/ncaa-sees-dollar-signs-in-sports-stats-signs-10-year-data-deal|title=NCAA Sees Dollar Signs in Sports Stats, Signs 10-Year Data Deal|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
The '''ISAF Sailing Hall of Fame''' is the World Sailing's [[Hall of Fame]] launched by the [[International Sailing Federation]].
== History == To mark the 100 anniversary of the [[International Sailing Federation]], the ISAF Sailing Hall of Fame was launched in 2007 to celebrate the persons across the world who have achieved greatness in the sport of sailing. Sailors will be inducted into the Hall of Fame every third year of the Executive Committee's tenure.
It has inducted sailors on two occasions: * [[Olin Stephens]], [[Ellen MacArthur]], [[Paul Elvstrøm]], [[Barbara Kendall]], [[Éric Tabarly]] and [[Robin Knox-Johnston]] were announced and awarded on 5 November 2007 at a dinner at the Estoril Casino, Estoril, Portugal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sailing.org/halloffame/inductees.php |title=Inductees |work=ISAF Sailing Hall of Fame}}</ref><ref name="Sailing.org">{{cite web |url=http://www.sailing.org/news/41428.php |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117034034/http://www.sailing.org/news/41428.php |archive-date=2015-11-17 |title=Seven Sailors inducted into World Sailing's Hall of Fame |website=Sailing.org |date=13 November 2015}}</ref> * [[Dennis Conner]], [[Alessandra Sensini]], [[Harold Stirling Vanderbilt|Harold Vanderbilt]], [[Peter Blake (sailor)|Peter Blake]], [[Buddy Melges]], [[Valentin Mankin]] and [[Torben Grael]] were inducted at the 2015 Annual Conference in Sanya, China.<ref name="Sailing.org" /><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sail-world.com/Volvo-Ocean-Race---Two-greats-inducted-into-World-Sailing-Hall-of-Fame/140053 |title=Volvo Ocean Race – Two greats inducted into World Sailing Hall of Fame |website=Sail-World.com |date=14 November 2015}}</ref>
The next induction will be in 2019.<ref name="Sailing.org" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.sailing.org/halloffame/home.php}} {{World Sailing navbox}} [[Category:Halls of fame in the United Kingdom|Sailing]] [[Category:Sports halls of fame]] [[Category:ISAF Sailing Hall of Fame| ]] [[Category:World Sailing]]

{{Use British English|date=August 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = KCOM Stadium | former_names = KC Stadium (2002–2016) | nickname = | logo_image = KCOM Stadium logo.png | image = KCOM Stadium.jpg | image_size = 240px | location = The Circle, Walton Street, Anlaby Road, [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]], [[East Riding of Yorkshire]], [[England]], HU3 6HU | coordinates = {{coord|53|44|46|N|0|22|4|W|type:landmark_scale:2000_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = December 2001 | opened = October 2002 | owner = [[Hull City Council]] / [[KCOM Group|KCOM]] | operator = Stadium Management Company (SMC) | surface = [[Desso GrassMaster]] | construction_cost = £44 million | architect = The Miller Partnership | tenants = [[Hull City A.F.C.]] ([[EFL Championship]]) (2003–present)
[[Hull F.C.]] ([[Super League]]) (2003–present) | seating_capacity = 25,400 ([[Association football|Football]] and [[rugby league]]){{cite web|url=http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/handbooks/premier-league-handbook-2013-14.pdf |title=Premier League Handbook Season 2013/14 |format=PDF |accessdate=17 August 2013 |work=[[Premier League]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140122060849/http://www.premierleague.com/content/dam/premierleague/site-content/News/publications/handbooks/premier-league-handbook-2013-14.pdf |archivedate=22 January 2014 }} |}} The '''KCOM Stadium''' (also known as the '''Hull City Stadium''' due to [[UEFA]] sponsorship regulations) is a multi-purpose facility in the city of [[Kingston upon Hull]], England. The stadium was previously called the '''KC Stadium''', but was renamed as part of a major rebrand by the stadium's sponsors, telecommunications provider [[KCOM Group|KCOM]], on 4 April 2016.{{cite web|title=Hull's KC Stadium to change name to KCOM Stadium|url=http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/Hull-s-KC-Stadium-change-KCOM-Stadium/story-28962649-detail/story.html|website=Hull Daily Mail|accessdate=17 April 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160701200005/http://www.hulldailymail.co.uk/hull-s-kc-stadium-change-kcom-stadium/story-28962649-detail/story.html|archivedate=1 July 2016|df=dmy-all}} Conceived in the late 1990s,{{cite web | title = Full Circle | publisher = Kingston upon Hull City Council | work = Hull in print | year = 2003 | url = http://static.hullcc.gov.uk/hullinprint/archive/december2002/full_circle.php | accessdate = 9 May 2010}} it was completed in 2002 at a cost of approximately £44 million. The stadium is owned by [[Hull City Council]] and operated by the Stadium Management Company (SMC),{{cite web | title = About the KC Stadium | url = http://www.kcstadium.co.uk/about-the-kc-stadium | work = KC Stadium | publisher = KCStadium.co.uk & SMC | year = 2010 | accessdate = 26 April 2016}} who are looking to expand the stadium up to 32,000. The bowl-shaped stadium contains a continuous single tier of seats with a second tier on the west side. Its current capacity is 25,400. The stadium hosts two tenants, [[association football]] club [[Hull City A.F.C.]], which moved there from [[Boothferry Park]], and [[Rugby league|rugby league football]] club [[Hull F.C.]], relocated from [[The Boulevard (stadium)|the Boulevard]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-humber-34301784|title=Hull FC's Boulevard Stadium memorial unveiled|last=|first=|date=19 September 2015|website=BBC News|publisher=|accessdate=20 September 2016}} It is also the [[List of Rugby League stadiums in England|2nd largest rugby league stadium in England]]. The ground also hosts international [[Football (soccer)|association football]] and [[Rugby league|rugby league football]] competitions and acts as a venue for concerts by musical artists, such as [[Elton John]] and [[The Who]]. ==History== [[File:KC Stadium.JPG|left|thumb|240px|The KCOM Stadium]] The idea of a new stadium for [[Kingston upon Hull]], whose professional football club Hull City had played at [[Boothferry Park]] since 1946, was first mooted in 1997, but funds to finance such a project only became available when the [[Hull City Council|city council]] sold a portion of its holdings in [[Kingston Communications]]. The council provided most of the funds, more than £42 million, with the rest stemming from government single regeneration budget grants and from the Football Stadium Improvement Fund. The council appointed John Topliss to head the stadium construction project. He and his team partnered with consulting firm [[Drivers Jonas]] to explore preliminary issues such as stadium location, [[seating capacity]], and facilities offered. Stated Mr. Topliss: "We had a totally blank canvas and, working with consultants, made a thorough assessment of what was needed." The project team considered over a dozen sites, inside and outside of the city, before settling on [[The Circle, Kingston upon Hull|The Circle]] in West Park. Factors contributing to the decision include transport guidance, central government planning guidelines, existing athletic facilities, isolation from residential areas, and council ownership. [[File:Kc under construction.jpg|thumb|right|The stadium under construction in 2002]] The final recommendation of [[Drivers Jonas]] included additional facilities for both indoor and outdoor sports for the people of West Hull in addition to the main stadium, planned to seat from 25,000 to 30,000 spectators. Professional services firm [[Arup Group Limited|Arup Associates]] provided initial concept proposals for the stadium. The Miller Partnership, an architectural and interior design firm, adopted these proposals during the stadium's design. In spite of obstacles during the course of the project, including [[Hull City A.F.C.]]'s receivership in 2001 (just after the granting of planning permission), the stadium complex was completed on time (in fourteen months) and on budget (at approximately [[pound sterling|GB£]]44 million). The stadium opened its doors on 18 December 2002. Hull City beat [[Sunderland A.F.C.]] 1–0 in a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] to mark the occasion.{{cite web |title=Home From Home |url=http://www.hullcityafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Stadium/0,,10338,00.html |publisher=Hull City AFC |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217193311/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/Stadium/0%2C%2C10338%2C00.html |archivedate=17 February 2012 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes }} [[Steve Melton]] scored the goal, the first at the KC Stadium.{{cite web |title=History Of The Tigers |url=http://www.hullcityafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/History/0,,10338,00.html |work=Hull City AFC: The Tigers: Official Site |publisher=Hull City Football Club & FL Interactive Ltd. |date=18 May 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210174952/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/History/0%2C%2C10338%2C00.html |archivedate=10 February 2012 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes }} ==Structure and facilities== {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;margin-left:1em;float:right" |+ Stand names and capacities |- ! Stand !! Location !! Capacity |- | [[Smith & Nephew]]{{cite web | title = Seating Plan | publisher = KCStadium.co.uk & SMC | year = 2010 | url = http://www.kcstadium.co.uk/site-includes/uploads/pdfs/SeatingPlan.pdf | format = PDF | work = KC Stadium | accessdate = 9 May 2010 }} || North || 4,000 |- | Ideal Boilers{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcityafc.net/news/article/201314-commercial-east-stand-sponsor-905842.aspx | title = New Sponsor For East Stand | date = 10 July 2013 | work = The Tigers Official website | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 10 July 2013}} || East || 6,000 |- | MKM{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcityafc.net/news/article/201314-mkm-extend-sponsorship-907414.aspx | title = MKM Extend Sponsorship | date = 11 July 2013 | work = The Tigers Official website | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 11 July 2013}} || South || 4,000 |- | rowspan=2 | Cranswick plc || Lower West || 6,000 |- | Upper West || 5,000 |} The all-seater stadium consists of a single-tier, asymmetrical bowl that can seat approximately 20,000, with a second tier on the Cranswick plc West Stand that can seat approximately 5,000. Current capacity is 25,586. Plans provide for future expansion to a capacity of approximately 30,000 by the addition of a second tier on the Ideal Standard Community East Stand. Each stand has a name for corporate sponsorship purposes. On 4 July 2011, Hull City revealed that the stadium's west stand would be sponsored by the local Cranswick plc under a two-year agreement,{{cite web |title=New Sponsor for the KC Stadium's West Stand |url=http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~2385783,00.html |work=The Tigers: Official Website |publisher=Hull City Football Club & FL Interactive Ltd. |date=4 July 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110905191920/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10338~2385783%2C00.html |archivedate= 5 September 2011 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes }} which was extended on 26 July 2013.{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcityafc.net/news/article/201314-cranswick-stand-sponsorship-946593.aspx | title = Cranswick PLC Extend Stand Sponsorship | date = 26 July 2013 | work = The Tigers: Official Website | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 26 July 2013}} On 10 July 2013 it was announced the east stand would be sponsored by Ideal Standard and become known as the Ideal Standard Community East Stand. Corporate hospitality is provided by 28 executive boxes located between the two tiers of the Cranswick plc West Stand, while security of the stadium is handled using 57 closed-circuit television (CCTV) cameras that cover the stadium. Over the summer of 2007, SMC installed an LED{{cite web | url = http://www.displayled.com/news.php?pg=story&id=82 | title = Scotland v Italy | publisher = displayled.com | accessdate = 11 December 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090330112422/http://displayled.com/news.php?pg=story&id=82 | archivedate = 30 March 2009}} screen in the Smith & Nephew North Stand to replace the old electronic scoreboard.{{cite web |title=Big Screen Installed |publisher=Hull City Football Club & FL Interactive Ltd. |date=9 August 2007 |url=http://www.hullcityafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10338~1088153,00.html |work=Hull City AFC: the Tigers: Official Site |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217193108/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10338~1088153%2C00.html |archivedate=17 February 2012 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |quote=Note – this reference incorrectly quotes the screen is made of LCDs. |deadurl=yes }} The screen has an area of approximately 40 m² (430 ft.²) and displays such content as live home game feeds, match highlights, interviews, and action replays. [[File:KC Stadium 1.jpg|left|thumb|240px|The stadium decorated with blue and gold accents]] The stadium's seats are mostly black, with a band of white and amber seats around the circumference. White and amber seats form the word ''[[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]]'' in the north and south stands. In the Ideal Standard Community East Stand, the seats form an image of a [[coronet]], a symbol of the city that also appears in the club crest for [[Hull F.C.]] and in the [[coat of arms]] of the city council.{{cite web | title = College of Arms Newsletter, August 2004: Recent Grants of Arms | publisher = The College of Arms |date=August 2004 | url = http://www.college-of-arms.gov.uk/Newsletter/002.htm | accessdate = 10 August 2007 }} Black, white, and amber were chosen to remain neutral toward the colours of its two tenants: black and white for Hull F.C.and black and amber for Hull City A.F.C.. The blue and gold of owner [[Hull City Council]] appear in the stadium's four external columns. The size of the playing surface is 114 x 74 metres (125 x 81 [[yard|yd]]) and made of rye grass with a 3% additive of artificial grass. This provides ample room for a [[FIFA]]-regulation [[association football]] pitch of 105 x 68 metres (115 x 74 [[yard|yd]]) and a standard [[rugby league football]] pitch of 100 x 68 metres (109 x 74 [[yard|yd]]). The playing surface has an automated watering system and below-surface heating. Set within Hull's West Park, the stadium is the first in England to be built in a parkland setting.{{cite web | title = About the stadium | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/humber/sport/stadium/new_stadium/about.shtml | work = BBC – Humber Sport – Stadium Facts | publisher = The British Broadcasting Corporation | year = 2007 | accessdate = 22 September 2008 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20031006230724/http://www.bbc.co.uk/humber/sport/stadium/new_stadium/about.shtml | archivedate = 6 October 2003}} The stadium complex also includes the 1,500 seat [[Bonus Arena]], a [[skate park]], two multi-use all-weather pitches, a community learning zone complete with classrooms, a health & fitness suite, a [[cyber cafe]], and a [[library]]. The KCOM Stadium has received several honours. It was named the chief new development in Yorkshire at the [[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors]] Pro-Yorkshire Awards.{{cite web | title = Another award goes to... | publisher = Kingston upon Hull City Council | work = Hull in print | year = 2003 | url = http://static.hullcc.gov.uk/hullinprint/archive/decjan20034/another_award_goes.php | accessdate = 9 May 2010}} It was also on the shortlist for the Prime Minister's Award for Better Public Building and received a high commendation in the British Construction Industry Awards in the Best Value category. In a 2005 poll that was carried out by [[Drivers Jonas]] and decided by football fans from across the country, the KC Stadium was rated highest in comfort, services and view among all grounds in the Football League{{ cite news | title = City has 'best' football stadium | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/humber/4206582.stm | publisher = The British Broadcasting Corporation | date = 2 September 2005 | accessdate = 5 August 2007}} and was also rated the most-improved venue. On 13 August 2013 a Goal Decision System by [[Hawk-Eye]] was installed in the ground ahead of the [[2013–14 Premier League]] season which requires the use of [[goal-line technology]] to indicate if a goal is scored.{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcityafc.net/news/article/201314-gds-technology-989888.aspx | title = GDS Arrives at the KC | date = 13 August 2013 | work = The Tigers Official Website | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 13 August 2013}} ==Tenants== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;margin-left:1em;float:right" |+ Hull City A.F.C. average attendances |- !
