A.F.C.=== The stadium replaced [[Boothferry Park]] as home to [[Hull City Association Football Club]], and was the backdrop for the club's recent climb through the English [[The Football League|Football League]]. It first hosted the club's home games during the second half of the [[2002–03 in English football|2002–03]] season; the first competitive match was against [[Hartlepool United F.C.|Hartlepool United]], a game that Hull City won by a score of 2–0.{{cite web |title=2002/2003: Hull City: Match: Fixtures & Results |url=http://www.hullcityafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/Fixtures/0,,10338~2002,00.html |work=Hull City AFC: the Tigers: Official Site |publisher=Hull City Football Club & FL Interactive Ltd. |year=2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210174720/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/Fixtures/0%2C%2C10338~2002%2C00.html |archivedate=10 February 2012 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes }} Hull City, nicknamed ''the Tigers'', attracted an average attendance of almost 17,000 in their first full season at the KC Stadium, 2003–04. This figure is more than three times the average Third Division attendance for that season, and was only matched or exceeded by clubs in the [[Premier League]] and the [[Football League First Division|First Division]].{{cite web | title = Average Attendances – English Football Divisions – 1994/95-2005/06 | url = http://www.footballeconomy.com/stats/stats_att_01.htm | work = The Political Economy of Football | publisher = Jez Booker | year = 2007 | accessdate = 10 August 2007}} However, the level of support was not matched by on-field performances; the Tigers finished 13th in their first season at the KC Stadium.{{cite web |title=2002/2003: Hull City: Match: Table |url=http://www.hullcityafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/LeagueTable/0,,10338~20030617,00.html |work=Hull City AFC: the Tigers: Official Site |publisher=Hull City Football Club & FL Interactive Ltd. |year=2003 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509200159/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/LeagueTable/0%2C%2C10338~20030617%2C00.html |archivedate= 9 May 2012 |accessdate=5 June 2013 |deadurl=yes }} However, in [[2003–04 in English football|2003–04]] (their first full season at the new ground), Hull won promotion as [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] runners-up, securing their place in the newly named [[Football League One|League One]] (previously the Second Division). A second successive promotion to the [[Football League Championship|Championship]], again as runners-up, followed in [[2004–05 in English football|2004–05]]. Attendances for Hull City's league games at the KCOM Stadium have averaged above 16,000 in each full season they have played there, apart from the 2017–18 season. The stadium hosted Premier League football in the 2008–09 and 2009–10 seasons, with all 20,500 available [[season ticket]]s selling out shortly after Hull City's Championship [[Football League play-offs|play-off]] victory at [[Wembley Stadium]].{{ cite news | title = Hull City sell out season tickets | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hull_city/7438727.stm | work = BBC Sport | date = 4 June 2008 | accessdate = 7 June 2008}} The record attendance for a Premier League match is 25,030 set on 9 May 2010 for the last match of the season against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]{{cite news | title = Hull 0 – 0 Liverpool | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8660536.stm | publisher = BBC | work = [[BBC Sport]] | date = 9 May 2010 | accessdate = 14 May 2010 | last = Reekie | first = Harry }} beating the previous record of 25,023 set on 13 March 2010 against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].{{cite news | title = Hull 1 – 2 Arsenal | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8558061.stm | publisher = BBC | work = [[BBC Sport]] | date = 13 March 2010 | accessdate = 15 March 2010 | last = Dawkes | first = Phil }} While playing in the Championship, the record stood at 24,350 on 26 April 2008 for the visit of [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], beating that of 24,311 on 30 January 2007 for the visit of local rivals [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]]. Segregation between home fans and away fans prevents the stadium's stated capacity from being reached. Plans have been prepared for the potential extension of the stadium following Hull City's promotion to the Premier League. 4,500 seats could be added in a second tier to the east stand, and 2,000 seats each in the north and south stands, giving the stadium a capacity of approximately 34,000.{{cite magazine |date=September 2009 | magazine = City Magazine | publisher = Hull City AFC | issue = 49 | page = 39}} In 2011, the club's owner [[Assem Allam]] announced that he wanted to buy the stadium [[Freehold (law)|freehold]] so he could develop, as he stated, "a sports park" on the site.{{cite news | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2320440/Hull-City-owner-Assem-Allam-snub-civic-reception-hold-celebrations.html | title = It'll be MY promotion party, says Allam | newspaper = [[The Daily Mail]] | date = 6 May 2013 | accessdate = 19 November 2013 | location=London | first=Colin | last=Young}}{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/hull_city/9355077.stm |title = Allams plan to buy KC Stadium from Hull City Council |date = 11 January 2011 |work = BBC Sport |publisher = BBC |accessdate = 14 January 2011}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;margin-left:1em;float:right" |+ Hull F.C. average attendances |- ! style="width:100px;"| Season !! style="width:100px;"| Attendance |- | 2015 || 11,343{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- | 2014 || 11,166{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- | 2013 || 11,640{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- | 2012 || 12,402{{citation needed|date=September 2015}} |- | 2011 || 12,483{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} |- | 2010 || 13,731{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} |- | 2009 || 13,244{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} |- | 2008 || 13,432{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} |- | 2007 || 14,606{{cite web | title = Super League Statistics – Hull FC | url = http://www.slstats.org/t9/Hull%20FC/ | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929090950/http://www.slstats.org/t9/Hull%20FC/ | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 29 September 2007 | publisher = RLFANS.COM | accessdate = 12 December 2011}} |- | 2006 || 10,866 |- | 2005 || 10,604 |- | 2004 || 11,458 |- | 2003 || 11,598 |} After [[Hull City Council]] refused, Allam stated "I had in mind £30 million to spend on the infrastructure of the club, to increase the stadium by 10,000 and to have commercial activities around the stadium – cafeterias, shops, supermarkets – to have all this to create income for the club so that in the future it can be self-financing and not relying on me."{{cite news | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/hull-city/10232633/Hull-City-irrelevant-says-owner-Assem-Allam.-From-now-on-we-will-be-known-as-Hull-Tigers.html | title = 'Hull City irrelevant', says owner Assem Allam | newspaper = [[The Daily Telegraph]] | date = 9 August 2013 | accessdate = 19 November 2013 | location=London | first=Radhika | last=Sanghani}} On 9 August 2013, Allam announced that the club will discard its 109-year-old name and, henceforth, be "marketed" as '''Hull City Tigers''' locally and '''Hull Tigers''' to national and international audiences. Announcing the change in the ''[[Hull Daily Mail]]'' newspaper, he said: "'Hull City' is irrelevant...it is common. I want the club to be special. It is about [[Corporate identity|identity]]. 'City' is a lousy identity. 'Hull City Association Football Club' is so long." The club's Managing Director Nick Thompson urged supporters "to judge it in the fullness of time."{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23629379 | title = Hull City AFC change name to Hull City Tigers | work = BBC Sport | date = 9 August 2013 | accessdate = 19 November 2013}} The announcement stated that all references to "AFC" on club branding will be phased out, although they will remain on the shirt crest during their [[2013–14 Premier League|first season back in the Premier League]]. Allam justified the name change as part of his plans to create "additional sources of revenue" for the club. He dismissed fans' protests against the name change, stating "nobody questions my decisions in my business."{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24920893 | title = Hull City: Tigers chairman dismisses fans' protests | work = BBC Sport | date = 12 November 2013 | accessdate = 19 November 2013 }} ===Hull F.C.=== Professional [[Rugby league|rugby]] league's [[Hull F.C.|Hull Football Club]] play their home games at the KCOM Stadium, having moved from [[The Boulevard (stadium)|the Boulevard]]. During their time at the KCOM Stadium, they have consistently ended each season on a high note: in 2003, the team just missed play-off qualification; in 2004, the club finished third. They finished fourth in 2005, and enjoyed even greater success in the [[Challenge Cup]], in which they beat the [[Leeds Rhinos]] in the final.{{cite web |title=Club History 2003 – To Present |url=http://www.hullfc.com/page.aspx?p=1003 |work=Welcome to the Official Hull FC Website |publisher=Hull FC |year=2008 |accessdate=23 April 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304063142/http://www.hullfc.com/page.aspx?p=1003 |archivedate=4 March 2016 }} Hull F.C. reached the [[Super League]] Grand Final in 2006.{{cite web |title=Previous Winners |url=http://www.superleague.co.uk/page.php?id=345 |work=engage Super League |publisher=Super League (Europe) Limited |year=2010 |accessdate=9 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523002036/http://www.superleague.co.uk/page.php?id=345 |archivedate=23 May 2010 }} Attendances average around 14,000, but are often well above that figure when the club hosts local rivals [[Hull Kingston Rovers]], this [[local derby]] producing a record crowd of 23,004 for 2 September 2007 fixture.{{cite web |title=SLStats: Hull FC 2007 Summary |url=http://www.slstats.org/t9/Hull+FC/2007/Summary.html |publisher=RLFANS.com |accessdate=9 May 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100329032151/http://www.slstats.org/t9/Hull%2BFC/2007/Summary.html |archivedate=29 March 2010 |deadurl=yes }} ==Other sporting events== It hosted four [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21]] internationals. The results were as follows. {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Date !! Opponents !! Result !! Attendance !! Part of |- | 2 June 2003 || {{fbu|21|SCG}} || 3 - 2 || 24,004 || rowspan=2|International friendly |- | 17 February 2004 || {{fbu|21|NED}} || 3 - 2 || 25,280{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/england-u21-vs-slovenia-u21/teams/2109 |title=Under-21 International |last= |first= |date=19 August 2008 |website=Sky Sports |publisher= |access-date=20 September 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161023013214/http://www.skysports.com/football/england-u21-vs-slovenia-u21/teams/2109 |archivedate=23 October 2016 }} |- | 25 March 2005 || {{fbu|21|GER}} || 2 - 2 || 21,746 || [[2006 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification#Group 6|2006 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification Group 6]] |- | 19 August 2008 || {{fbu|21|SVN}} || 2 - 1 || || International friendly |} The KCOM Stadium is now also a regular venue for international [[rugby league]] games, and has hosted [[Great Britain national rugby league team|Great Britain]] matches in both the [[Rugby League Tri-Nations|Tri-Nations]] and the [[Rugby League Ashes|Ashes]]{{cite news | title = What are the Ashes all about? | work = BBC Sport Academy | publisher = The British Broadcasting Corporation | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sportacademy/hi/sa/rugby_league/features/newsid_3197000/3197488.stm | accessdate = 5 August 2007 | date=20 October 2003}} competitions. The stadium hosted the 2004 Tri-Nations match in which New Zealand lost by a score of 26–24. {{cite news | title = Carney keeps Lions' eye on the final ball | work = guardian.co.uk | publisher = Guardian News and Media Limited | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2004/nov/21/rugbyleague.trinations2004 | accessdate = 9 May 2010 | location = London | date = 21 November 2004 | first = David | last = Lawrenson}} The stadium also hosted the Tri-Nations game between Great Britain and Australia in 2005; the final score was 26–14 to Australia. {{cite news | title = Lions never in hunt | work = guardian.co.uk | publisher = Guardian News and Media Limited | url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2005/nov/20/rugbyleague.trinations2005 | accessdate = 9 May 2010 | location = London | date = 20 November 2005 | first = David | last = Lawrenson}} On Saturday 9 November 2013, the stadium hosted the England versus Fiji Rugby League World Cup match, in which England won 34–12 in front of an attendance of 25,114. Before the match, there was a minute's silence, followed by spontaneous applause, to mark the early death of former England International [[Steve Prescott]].{{cite news |url=http://www.code13rugbyleague.com/2012/07/23/rugby-league-world-cup-2013-fixtures-announced/ |title=Rugby League World Cup 2013 fixtures announced |date=23 July 2012 |work=Code 13 Rugby League |accessdate=25 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120926135213/http://www.code13rugbyleague.com/2012/07/23/rugby-league-world-cup-2013-fixtures-announced/ |archivedate=26 September 2012 }}{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/rugby-league/24867379 | title = Rugby League World Cup 2013: England 34–12 Fiji | date = 9 November 2013 |work = BBC Sport |publisher = BBC | accessdate = 9 November 2013}} In 2009, the KC Stadium was shortlisted as a possible venue for games at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] should England win the right to host it, but when the list of venues was announced on 16 December that year, the KC Stadium was not included.{{cite news |url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/8414235.stm |title = Milton Keynes chosen for England's 2018 World Cup bid |date = 16 December 2009 |work = BBC Sport |publisher = BBC |accessdate = 27 September 2010}} It has also played host to two exhibition Twenty20 cricket matches between [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club]] and [[Lashings World XI]].{{cite journal |date=June 2004 |title = International Cricket Returns to the KC Stadium |journal = East Riding News |publisher = East Riding of Yorkshire Council |page = p. 24}} ==Concerts== As well as serving as a sporting venue, the KCOM Stadium also hosts musical events, including such artists as [[Elton John|Sir Elton John]],{{cite web | title = Slide Shows: Elton John at the KC | work = This Is Hull & East Riding | publisher = Northcliffe Media Ltd. | year = 2006 | url = http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/galleries/Elton-John-KC-gallery-176036-detail/gallery.html | accessdate = 11 December 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120426180041/http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/pictures/Elton-John-at-the-KC/pictures-11980358-detail/pictures.html | archivedate = 26 April 2012 }} [[Bryan Adams]],{{cite web | title = Music Live Band Reviews | work = thisisULL.com | publisher = www.thisisULL.com | year = 2004 | url = http://www.thisisull.com/music/stevekc26june04.html | accessdate = 9 May 2010}} [[Neil Diamond]],{{cite web | title = Neil Diamond Concert Setlist | work = Event Reviews | publisher = setlist.fm | year = 2005 | url = http://www.setlist.fm/setlist/neil-diamond/2005/kingston-communication-stadium-kingston-upon-hull-england-13ddb981.html | accessdate = 19 November 2014}} [[R.E.M.]],{{cite web | title = REM at the KC stadium | work = Event Reviews | publisher = BBC Humber | year = 2005 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/humber/content/articles/2005/07/07/rem_review_lucougar.shtml | accessdate = 9 May 2010}} [[Bon Jovi]],{{cite web | title = Music Reviews | work = thisisULL.com | publisher = www.thisisULL.com | year = 2006 | url = http://www.thisisull.com/music06/kcstadium/451251504_stevebonjovi13june06.html | accessdate = 9 May 2010}} and [[The Who]].{{cite web | title = KC Stadium in talks over music festival | work = This Is Hull & East Riding | publisher = Northcliffe Media Ltd. | date = 23 March 2009 | url = http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/news/KC-Stadium-talks-music-festival/article-788503-detail/article.html | accessdate = 11 December 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120426180117/http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/KC-Stadium-talks-music-festival/story-11947009-detail/story.html | archivedate = 26 April 2012 }} JLS have also performed here in front of 20,000 fans as part of their 2010 [[JLS Tour]]. [[Rod Stewart]] performed at the stadium on 14 June 2016{{cite news | url = http://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/article/rod-stewart-the-hits-2016-concert-live-at-the-kc-stadium-2714660.aspx | title = Rod Stewart - The Hits 2016 Concert - Live At The KC Stadium | date = 28 September 2015 | publisher = Hull City A.F.C. | accessdate = 10 June 2016}} and [[Jeff Lynne's ELO]] played at the stadium on 1 July 2017.{{cite news | url = http://www.yorkshirepost.co.uk/what-s-on/music/gig-review-jeff-lynne-s-elo-at-wembley-stadium-1-8616109 | title = Gig review: Jeff Lynne’s ELO at Wembley Stadium | date = 26 June 2017 | work = The Yorkshire Post | accessdate = 10 July 2017}} ==Rugby League Test Matches== List of test, league and International tournament matches played at KCOM Stadium since its opening in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/matches/Custom/LS0tMS0tNjMtLS0tLS0tLXkteS0tLS0tLQ==|title=KC Stadium|work= Rugby League Project|accessdate=17 May 2014}} {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Game# !! Date !! Result !! Attendance !! Notes |- |1 || 15 November 2003 || {{rl|AUS}} def. {{rl|GBR}} 23–20 || 25,147 || [[2003 Kangaroo tour|2003]] [[The Ashes (rugby league)|Ashes series]] |- |2 || 20 November 2004 || {{rl|GBR}} def. {{rl|NZL}} 26–24 || 23,377 || [[2004 Rugby League Tri-Nations]] |- |3 || 19 November 2005 || {{rl|AUS}} def. {{rl|GBR}} 26–14 || 25,150 || [[2005 Rugby League Tri-Nations]] |- |4 || 5 November 2006 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|SAM}} 38–14 || 5,698 || [[Federation Shield|2006 Federation Shield]] |- |5 || 3 November 2007 || {{rl|GBR}} def. {{rl|NZL}} 44–0 || 20,324 || [[2007 All Golds Tour|2007]] [[Baskerville Shield]] |- |6 || 12 November 2011 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|NZL}} 28–6 || 23,447 || [[2011 Rugby League Four Nations]] |- |7 || 9 November 2013 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|FIJ}} 34–12 || 25,114 || [[2013 Rugby League World Cup|2013]] [[Rugby League World Cup]] [[2013 Rugby League World Cup Group A|Group A]] |- |8 || 1 November 2015 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|NZL}} 26–12 || 23,526 || [[2015 New Zealand rugby league tour of Great Britain|2015]] [[Baskerville Shield]] |- |9 || 27 October 2018 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|NZL}} 18-16 || 17,649 || [[2018 New Zealand rugby league tour of Great Britain|2018]] [[Baskerville Shield]] |} ==Gallery==

{{Orphan|date=September 2015}}
'''''Kick in Iran''''' is a feature documentary by Fatima Geza Abdollahyan.<ref>[http://www.identitytheory.com/kick-in-iran/ Kick in Iran - Identity Theory<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It portrays Taekwondo fighter [[Sara Khoshjamal-Fekri]] on her way to the [[Olympic Games 2008]], in Beijing. <ref>[http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/kick-iran-film-review-29214 Kick in Iran - Film Review - The Hollywood Reporter<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.screendaily.com/reviews/kick-in-iran/5009928.article "Kick In Iran"]. ''Screen Daily'', 26 January 2010 | By David D'Arcy (paywall)</ref> Sara Khoshjamal Fekri is the first female athlete from [[Iran]] to ever qualify directly for the Olympic Games.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/iranian-taekwondo-star-in-spotlight-at-sundance-1884647.html "Iranian taekwondo star in spotlight at Sundance"]. ''The Independent'', 31 January 2010</ref>
== Synopsis == The movie follows Sara Khoshjamal-Fekri and her coach Maryam Azarmehr during a nine-month period, beginning with qualification and including participation in the Olympic Games 2008. Because they live in a [[Muslim world|Muslim country]], the two athletes have to face a lot of challenges.<ref>[http://www.slugmag.com/festival-coverage/kick-in-iran-review/ "Kick in Iran – Review"]. ''SLUG Magazine'', By Jimmy Martin January 24, 2010</ref><ref>[http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2010/01/28/irans-cinematic-revolution.html "Iran's Cinematic Revolution"]. ''The Daily Beast''.</ref> They work hard as they prepare to represent the Islamic Republic of Iran as female Taekwondo-fighters.<ref>[http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705358558/Must-see-foreign-documentaries.html?pg=all "Must-see foreign documentaries"]. by Don Marshall for the ''Deseret News'' Jan. 15 2010</ref>
''Kick in Iran'' portrays day-to-day life in the Iran for two women while wearing both the ''[[hijab]]'' and the ''[[dobok]]''.<ref>[https://variety.com/2010/film/reviews/kick-in-iran-1117942000/ Kick in Iran | Variety<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
== Festivals == *[[Sundance Film Festival]] 2010 (world premiere), USA<ref>[http://www.screenjunkies.com/movies/genres-movies/documentary/5-best-iran-documentaries/ "5 Best Iran Documentaries"]. ''Screen Junkies'', March 26 by Andrea Miller</ref><ref>[http://www.sltrib.com/faith/ci_14240349 "Sundance: Muezzins and mohawks"]. By Ben Fulton, ''The Salt Lake Tribune''</ref> *True/False Film Festival, USA *Dallas International Filmfestival, USA *Visions du Reel, Switzerland *International Aljazeera Dokumentary Film Festival, Qatar *Filmfest Munich, Germany *Warsaw Film Festival, Poland *Mumbai Film Festival, India *Cine//B Film Festival, Chile *Corona Cork Filmfest, Ireland *International Images Film Festival for Women, Zimbabwe *Belgrade Documentary and Short Film Festival, Serbia *BAFICI, Argentina *Chennai International Film Festival, India *Noor Iranian Film Festival, USA *Film Festival for Women’s Rights, FIWOM, South Korea
== Awards == *Gerd Ruge Award, Germany *Special mentions, 13th BAFICI, UNICEF AWARD *Special mentions, 26th Warsaw Filmfestival *Nominated for the Grand Jury Award of the Sundance Filmfestival 2010
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|1562347}} *[http://www.kickiniran.com/ Official website] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k1xi0HHxBvw&feature=player_embedded Trailer], YouTube

[[Asmara]], [[Eritrea]] | capacity = 20,000 | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Eritrean Premier League]] | pattern_la1=|pattern_b1=|pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=ff0000|body1=ff0000|rightarm1=ff0000|shorts1=ff0000|socks1=ff0000 | season = 2006/07 | position = | }} '''Red Sea Football Club''' is an [[Eritrea]]n [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Asmara]]. In 2011 after a regional tournament in Tanzania, 13 team members didn't return home but have asked for political asylum.{{cite web|title=Eritrean Red Sea FC footballers seek Tanzania asylum|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14119890|publisher=BBC|accessdate=12 September 2011|date=12 July 2011}} ==Achievements== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2011}} *'''[[Eritrean Premier League]]: 12''' ::1995, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2002, 2005, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012, 2013, 2014. ==Performance in CAF competitions== {{Unreferenced section|date=October 2011}} *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 5 appearances''' ::1999 – Preliminary Round ::2000 – Preliminary Round ::2001 – First Round ::2003 – Preliminary Round ::2006 – Preliminary Round ==References== {{reflist}} {{Eritrean Premier League}} {{Eritrea-footyclub-stub}} [[Category:Football clubs in Eritrea]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Rock/Creek | logo = Rockcreek-logo.png | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]] 1987 | location_city = Chattanooga, Tennessee | key_people = Dawson Wheeler and Marvin Webb, co-founders, Jonathan Scott, [[vice president]] | industry = [[Retail]] [[Outdoor Industry]] | products = Clothing and outdoor equipment | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | num_employees = 50-99 | homepage = [http://www.rockcreek.com/ Rock/Creek] }}
'''Rock/Creek''' is a [[Chattanooga, Tennessee]]-based [[sporting goods]] [[retailer]] of clothing and gear for [[rock climbing]], [[paddling]], [[trail running]], [[hiking]], [[camping]] and [[travel]].
==History== Founded as Rock/Creek Outfitters and Canoeist Headquarters in 1987 when Dawson Wheeler and Marvin Webb purchased Canoeist Headquarters, the company became known as Rock/Creek Outfitters. The name was shortened to Rock/Creek in 2007.
In November 2007, Rock/Creek was named one of the top 25 specialty outdoor retailers by ''Outdoor Business'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.snewsnet.com/cgi-bin/snews/10371.html|title=16 Grassroots Outdoor Alliance members receive honors|publisher=Snews|date=2007-11-16|accessdate=2008-01-11}}</ref> In 2009, SNEWS & [[Backpacker Magazine]] chose Rock/Creek as Retailer of the Year for Best Online Business.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.snewsnet.com/cgi-bin/snews/Retailer_of_the_Year_Best_Online_Business_Rock_Creek_09.html|title=Retailer of the Year - Best Online Business: Rock/Creek puts a personal touch on web sales|publisher=Snews|date=2009-05-11|accessdate=2010-05-21}}</ref>
Rock/Creek has a total of five brick-and-mortar locations. They have two flagship stores, one in downtown Chattanooga and the other at [[Hamilton Place (shopping mall)|Hamilton Place Mall]], two paddling stores and an [[e-commerce]] site. In 2007, Rock/Creek opened a new store in the Two North Shore development in downtown Chattanooga.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wdef.com/video/two_north_shores_opens_in_north_chattanooga_with_green_theme/11/2007|title=Two North Shore Opens in North Chattanooga with Green Theme|publisher=WDEF News12|date=November 2007|accessdate=2008-01-11}}</ref> The project, developed by CS & Associates and Greenlife Grocery, has been designed with [[U.S. Green Building Council]]'s [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] standards in mind.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesfreepress.com/absolutenm/templates/business-toplocal.aspx?articleid=14496&zoneid=169|title=Idealism, marketing drives companies to go green|publisher=Chattanooga Times Free Press|date=2007-04-29|accessdate=2008-01-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071115213132/http://www.timesfreepress.com/absolutenm/templates/business-toplocal.aspx?articleid=14496&zoneid=169 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-11-15}}</ref> The latest store to open is located at The Block, the largest [[adaptive reuse]] project in Chattanooga.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.getoutchattanooga.com/news/2012/dec/31/joining-block-party/|title=Joining the Block Party|publisher=Get Out Chattanooga|date=2012-12-31|accessdate=2014-02-03}}</ref>
Rock/Creek selected [[Art Technology Group]] to revamp its Web site in Fall 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/rockcreek-to-revamp-web-presence-with-atg-commerce-2010-05-17?reflink=MW_news_stmp|title=Rock/Creek to Revamp Web Presence with ATG Commerce|publisher=MarketWatch.com|date=2010-05-17|accessdate=2010-05-20}}</ref> Since that date, the company has been listed on Internet Retailer's "Second 500" list. For the 2012 list they were #644.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.internetretailer.com/second500/list/?page=2|title=Internet Retailer Second 500 List|publisher=internetretailer.com|date=2012-02-14|accessdate=2012-02-14}}</ref>
In October 2014, a Chattanooga shop employee pursued a shoplifter on foot and the story went viral after being picked up by Trail Runner Magazine.<ref>http://trailrunnermag.com/people/news/1515-shoplifter-gets-schooled-by-ultrarunners</ref>
==Charity and environmental initiatives== Rock/Creek regularly gives money to environmental non-profits and sponsors trail building and cleanup efforts. The retailer created the Rock/Creek [[StumpJump 50k]] in 2002 to raise awareness and funds for the [[Cumberland Trail]]. This race has expanded and now forms part of a larger Rock/Creek Trail Series, with trail running events throughout the year ranging from 5 miles to 50 miles.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://ultrarunningnews.com/2010/02/rockcreek-trail-series-se-tennessee/|title=Rock/Creek Trail Series – SE Tennessee|publisher=ultrarunningnews.com|date=2010-02-27|accessdate=2010-05-20|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100304085456/http://ultrarunningnews.com/2010/02/rockcreek-trail-series-se-tennessee/|archivedate=2010-03-04|df=}}</ref> Past campaigns have included working with [[Chaco (footwear)|Chaco]] [[footwear]] to send used shoes to orphans in [[Nepal]] through the [[dZi Foundation]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.treehugger.com/files/2006/07/if_the_shoe_fit.php|title=If the Shoe Fits, Spare It- Rock/Creek, Chaco and dZi|publisher=Treehugger.com|date=2006-07-16|accessdate=2008-01-11}}</ref>
Rock/Creek has been featured in local media for its involvement in local trail races as well as the 3 State 3 Mountain Challenge, a bike century.<ref>http://nooga.com/168762/rockcreek-aims-to-draw-national-attention-to-scenic-city-with-outdoor-events/</ref>
==Affiliations== Rock/Creek is a member of the Grassroots Outdoor Alliance, a group of independent outdoor shops dedicated to the sustainability of the specialty outdoor channel and the quality of the outdoor enthusiast’s experience.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://grassrootsoutdoors.com/index.php/about/|title=About the Grassroots Outdoor Alliance|publisher=Grassroots Outdoor Alliance|date=2007-03-13|accessdate=2008-01-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071217121451/http://grassrootsoutdoors.com/index.php/about/ <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-12-17}}</ref> The retailer is also a member of the Outdoor Industry Association.
Rock/Creek employees serve on nonprofit boards as well. Founder Dawson Wheeler serves on the board of SAWS (Southern Appalachian Wilderness Stewards).<ref>http://www.trailcrews.org/board-of-directors/</ref> Marketing Director Mark McKnight serves on the board of local land trust Lula Lake Land Trust.<ref>http://lulalake.org/about/staff-and-board-of-directors</ref> Wheeler has been involved in lobbying for wilderness protection in the Cherokee National Forest and is cited in press interviews around the topic.<ref>http://www.johnsoncitypress.com/article/125230/corker-alexander-sponsored-tennessee-wilderness-act-gets-reintroduced</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://rockcreek.com/ Rock/Creek] website * [https://www.flickr.com/groups/rockcreek/ Rock/Creek Flickr Group] * [http://blog.rockcreek.com/archives/rockcreek-to-expand-paddling-store-and-distribution-center-in-chattanooga-tn.html/ Rock/Creek Expansion]

{{unref|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Samurai Sportswear | logo = Samurai_Sportswear.jpg | type = | traded_as = | predecessor = | revenue = $50 mil. - $100 mil. | founder = Terry Sands | fate = | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | industry = [[Sporting goods]] | products = [[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] | services = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | footnotes = | intl = | homepage = {{URL|www.samurai-sports.com}} | foundation = 1996 | location_city = [[Long Stratton, Norfolk|Long Stratton]], [[Norfolk]] | location_country = [[United Kingdom]] | location = | locations = Great Britain, Dubai, Australia, New Zealand, Hong Kong, Kenya, Asia, North America }}
'''Samurai Sportswear Limited''' is a privately owned English sportswear brand specialising in the manufacturing of custom made team wear and leisurewear garments for sports clubs, schools and universities around the world. With a heritage of manufacturing for rugby, Samurai Sportswear now supplies garments for a wide range of sports including [[Rugby football|Rugby]], [[Hockey]], [[Cricket]] and [[Netball]].
The Company name comes from the Samurai 7's team, regarded as the world's most successful invitational [[Rugby Sevens]] team. The team name was inspired by 'Samurai spirit' and the free-flowing rugby and belief shown by the [[Japan national rugby union team|Japanese team]] at the [[1995 Rugby World Cup]] in South Africa.
From its head office Long Stratton, [[Norfolk]] the Company supplies kits around the world.
Unlike most of its competitors Samurai Sportswear manufacturers garments at its own factory in [[China]], providing customers access to the latest garment and fabric technology and the most skilled garment technicians in the world.
==Clubs, Associations, Schools & Universities== More than a thousand clubs, schools and universities around the world wear Samurai Sportswear kit, including: *[[Exeter Chiefs]] *[[Kent Cricket]] *[[Sale Sharks]] *[[University of Derby]] *[[Kenya Rugby Union]] *[[University of Worcester]] *[[Army Rugby Union]] *[[Derbyshire CCC]] *[[Swansea University]] *[[Doncaster R.F.C.|Doncaster Knights]] *[[The John Fisher School]] *[[City, University of London]] *[[Portuguese Rugby Federation|Federação Portuguesa de Rugby]] *[[Royal Holloway, University of London]] *[[Merchiston Castle School]] *[[Uganda Rugby Union]] *[[Blackheath FC]] *[[Guildford Rugby Club]] *[[Wellington School, Somerset]]
==External links== * [http://www.samurai-sports.com/ Official website]
[[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Companies established in 1996]]

revision.text:
[[File:Sea Kayak.JPG|right|thumb|300px|A modern sea kayak off west Wales]] [[File:Kayak-Valdes-BC.jpg|right|thumb|300px|A sea kayak on [[Valdes Island]], [[British Columbia]], [[Canada]]]] A '''sea kayak''' or '''touring kayak''' is a [[kayak]] developed for the sport of [[Watercraft paddling|paddling]] on open waters of lakes, bays, and the ocean. Sea kayaks are [[seaworthy]] small boats with a covered deck and the ability to incorporate a [[spray deck]]. They trade off the maneuverability of [[whitewater]] kayaks for higher cruising speed, cargo capacity, ease of straight-line paddling, and comfort for long journeys.
Sea kayaks are used around the world for marine (sea) journeys from a few hours to many weeks, as they can accommodate one to three paddlers together with room for camping gear, food, water, and other supplies. A sea kayak usually ranges anywhere from {{convert|10|–|18|ft|m|abbr=none|sp=us}} for solo craft, and up to {{convert|26|ft|m|abbr=none|sp=us}} for tandem craft. Width may be as little as {{convert|21|in|cm|abbr=on}}, and may be up to {{convert|36|in|cm|abbr=on}}.
==Origins== {{main|Kayak}} [[File:Greenland kayak seal hunter 2006.jpg|thumb|right|[[Inuit]] seal hunter in a kayak, armed with a harpoon.]] Contemporary sea kayaks trace their origin to the native boats of [[Alaska]], northern [[Canada]], and Southwest [[Greenland]]. [[Eskimo]] hunters developed a fast seagoing craft to hunt [[Earless seal|seals]] and [[walrus]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Hutchinson | first = Derek. C. | title = The Complete Book of Sea Kayaking | publisher = A&C Black | year = 1994 | pages = 177–181 | isbn = 0-7136-6675-7 }}</ref> The ancient [[Aleut people|Aleut]] name for a sea [[kayak]] is ''Iqyak'',<ref>[http://shamankayaks.com/shaman/taks/schedule_mike_livingston.asp Traditional Arctic Kayak Symposium (TAKS) San Simeon California<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and earliest models were constructed from a light wooden frame (tied together with [[sinew]] or [[baleen]]) and covered with [[sea mammal]] ([[sea lion]] or [[Pinniped|seal]]) hides. Archaeologists have found evidence indicating that kayaks are at least 4000 years old.<ref>[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/article/0,,2-2521235,00.html Made in Anglesey, paddled in the Arctic: the Inuits' plastic kayak rules the waves] ''TimesOnline'' December 2006</ref> Wooden kayaks and fabric kayaks on wooden frames (such as the [[folding kayak|Klepper]]) dominated the market up until the 1950s, when fiberglass boats were introduced. [[rotomolding|Rotomolded]] [[plastic]] kayaks first appeared in 1984.
==Design== [[File:Recreational kayak.jpg|thumbnail|Kayaking in a double on Lake Union in Seattle, USA]] Modern sea kayaks come in a wide array of materials, designs, and sizes to suit a variety of intended uses. In sea kayaking, where the designs continue along primarily traditional lines, the primary distinction is between ''rigid'' kayaks and ''[[Folding kayak|folding]]'' kayaks. Folding kayaks are in some ways more traditional boats, being similar in design to ''[[Skin-on-frame kayak|skin-on-frame]]'' kayaks used by native people. Modern folding kayaks use [[fraxinus|ash]] and [[birch]] or contemporary materials such as [[aluminum]] for the frame, and replace the [[sealskin]] covering with synthetic waterproof fabrics. Unlike native kayaks, folding kayaks can be easily disassembled and packed for transport. Many folding kayaks include inflatable [[sponsons]] that improve the [[secondary stability]] of the vessel, helping to prevent capsize. More recently, a class of inflatable folding kayaks has emerged, combining a more limited rigid frame with a tightly inflated skin to produce greater rigidity than an inflatable boat alone.
In recent years, there has been an increase in production of sit on top kayaks suitable for sea use. This has resulted in a new market for paddlers looking for the versatility of a sit on top, with seaworthy performance. Sit on top kayaks are a common choice for sea kayakers who prefer the sit on top versatility, but do not want to sacrifice performance.
Most rigid sea kayaks also derive from the external designs of native vessels, especially those from Greenland, but the strength of modern materials such as [[fiberglass]], [[rotomolding|rotomolded plastic]] and [[carbon fiber]] eliminate the need for an internal frame, though significantly increasing weight. Modern ''[[Skin-on-frame kayak|skin-on-frame]]'' sea kayaks constructed with [[nylon]] skins represent an ultralight niche within the rigid sea kayak spectrum. Some recent design innovations include: * [[Recreational kayak|Recreational]] kayaks—shorter kayaks with wide beams and large cockpits intended for sheltered waters * Sit-on-top kayaks—boats without an enclosed cockpit, but with the basic hull shape of a kayak.
A different class of vessel emerged in the 1960s, the [[Surf ski]], a long, narrow boat with low inherent stability that is intended for use in surf and [[following waves]].
===Size=== Most production sea kayaks are between {{convert|12|and|24|ft|m|2}} in length, the larger kayaks often built for two (or in rare cases, three) paddlers. The width ([[Beam (nautical)|beam]]) of typical kayaks varies from {{convert|18|to|32|in|mm|0}}, though specialized boats such as [[surf skis]] may be narrower. The length of a kayak affects not only its cargo capacity (for both gear and paddlers) but may also affect its "tracking" ability—the ease with which the boat travels in a straight line. While other design features also impact tracking, very long kayaks are easier to paddle straight (and harder to turn). The width of a kayak affects the cargo capacity, the maximum size of the cockpit (and thus the size of the paddler in that cockpit), and (to a degree that depends on the design of the hull) the [[Stability conditions (watercraft)|stability]].
===Material=== [[File:Plywood Sea Kayak.jpg|thumbnail|A sea kayak constructed from plywood, epoxy and fibreglass]]Most rigid production kayaks are now made out of [[fiberglass]], [[rotomolding|rotomolded polyethylene]], thermoformed plastic, blow moulded polyethylene or [[carbon]]-[[kevlar]]. More exotic materials include [[carbon fiber]] and [[foam core]]. Some kayaks are hand-built from [[plywood]] or wood strips covered with [[fiberglass]]. Skin-on-frame kayaks are built on wood or aluminum frames covered in [[canvas]], [[dacron]], or other fabrics, and may include inflatable tubes called [[sponsons]].
Marine Grade plywood available today provides a high strength to weight ratio for kayak construction.
===Bow, stern, and deck=== There are many design approaches for the bow, stern, and deck of kayaks. Some kayaks have upturned bows, which are meant to provide better performance when paddling into waves, as well as better wave-shedding ability. Other kayaks achieve this through increased [[buoyancy]] in the bow. Kayaks with unobstructed stern decks may ease certain types of [[self-rescue]]. Waterproof bulkheads in modern kayaks provide flotation in the event of capsize.
Sea kayak decks typically include one or more hatches for easy access to the interior storage space inside. Kayak decks often include attachment points for ''deck lines'' of various kinds, which are aids in self-rescue and attachment points for above-deck equipment.
Cockpits can be of several designs. They can be large or small. A large [[keyhole]] cockpit can give the advantages of both, and combine firm contact between paddler and boat, while offering relatively easier access.
===Equipment=== [[File:Sea Kayak Kealakekua.jpg|right|thumb|Sea kayaking is a popular way to explore [[Kealakekua Bay]], Hawaii.]] Sea Kayaks have a wide range of hull designs, which greatly expands their range of performance. Designs can accommodate a wide range of physical fitness, or usage. Boats come in many lengths, whereby shorter boats are generally more maneuverable, and longer boats generally travel straighter and faster. Width of beam can affect a boat's stability, speed, and ability to bring to an edge. The amount of rocker (the curve from bow to stern) can greatly affect the ability of a boat to turn.
Many have steering gear or tracking aids in the form of [[rudder]]s or [[skeg]]s. In most cases rudders are attached at the stern and operated by lines (wire or synthetics such as [[Ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene|Spectra]]) from foot pedals in the cockpit. Rudders are typically retractable for beach landings. Skegs are typically retractable straight blades that drop from a well in the stern of the boat. Both devices assist in paddling when a strong wind or waves are coming from a direction other than directly in front.<ref>{{cite book | last = Hutchinson | first = Derek. C. | title = The Complete Book of Sea Kayaking | publisher = A&C Black | year = 1994 | pages = 3–4 | isbn = 0-7136-6675-7 }}</ref> Some Skegs may be more effective at countering [[Pitch (aviation)|pitch]], [[Flight dynamics (fixed-wing aircraft)|roll]] and [[Yaw (rotation)|yaw]].<ref name="Watson">{{cite web |url=http://www.paddling.net/guidelines/showArticle.html?show=779 |title=Rudders & Skegs: Maneuvering Aids |first1=Tom |last1=Watson |publisher=paddling.net |date=February 12, 2014 |accessdate=February 12, 2014}}</ref><ref name="sea kayaker">{{cite journal |url=http://www.seakayakermag.com/forums/ubbthreads.php?ubb=showflat&Number=865 |journal=[[Sea Kayaker Magazine]] |title=Rudders vs Skegs |date=May 28, 2008 |accessdate=February 15, 2014}}</ref><ref name="chesapeake">{{cite web |url=http://www.clcboats.com/shoptips/fitting_out/retractable_skeg.html |title=Fixing up your boat: Installing a retractable skeg |publisher=Chesapeake Lightcraft |accessdate=February 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=gnarlydog |url=http://gnarlydognews.blogspot.com/2009/02/shop-kayak-mods-fabricating-skeg-box.html |title=Retrofitting your ruddered kayak with a skegg |publisher=gnarlydognews |accessdate=February 15, 2014}}</ref><ref name="atlantic">{{cite web |url=http://www.atlantickayaktours.com/pages/expertcenter/equipment/skeg/Skeg-1.shtml |title=How does a kayak skeg work |publisher=Atlantic Kayak Tours |year=2013 |accessdate=February 15, 2014}}</ref>
==Paddles== Sea-kayak [[paddle]]s, and the associated paddling styles, fall into three basic classifications: * European {{citation needed|date=October 2016}} : two roughly spoon-shaped blades at either end of a cylindrical shaft. This paddle style was developed for fast acceleration and sudden maneuvering in [[Whitewater kayaking]], and then back-ported to sea-kayaking. Euro {{citation needed|date=October 2016}} paddles can be made of aluminum, plastic or even wood, but the best are usually formed of more expensive materials like carbon-fiber for lightness. Often the two blades are ''feathered'', or set at an angle relative to each other (both for ergonomic efficiency, and so that as one blade moves backwards through the water, the opposite blade moving forward through the air presents its edge, rather than its face). This does make it less efficient with the wind on the side or behind.
[[File:PaddleForKayakTopAndAxisView.svg|center|500px|thumb|A European{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} style kayak paddle, (a) top view, (b) axial view, ([[first angle projection]])]] * Greenland : Relatively narrow blades which are rounded and full near the loom and blade roots, and becoming oval near the blade tips. Some paddles feature a "shoulder", or abrupt transition between the loom and blade roots. Greenland paddle blades are usually never feathered. Short Greenland paddles (generally one arm-span in length), called storm paddles, are used with a sliding stroke, where the hands are shifted along the blades for each stroke. Storm paddles are often used as spares and in very windy locations, as there is very little outboard blade to catch the wind. [[File:Greenland Paddle 2.JPG|center|500px|thumb|A Greenland style kayak paddle]] * Wing : The blade of the paddle is shaped with a profile like a wing. When used with a special stroke, the blade actually produces lift as it moves through the water, enabling the kayaker to produce more forward motion than with any other kind of paddle. The paddling technique is different from the European style paddle though the same motion is how the Greenland paddle works with its narrow blade. It is most often used in racing, but also sees some limited use in recreational paddling such as touring.
===Dimensions=== True Sea kayaks, not to be mistaken for wider, more stable recreational kayaks, come in many designs. The length of a solo sea kayak can range anywhere from {{convert|14|to|20|ft|m}} long, and tandem kayaks can range from {{convert|18|to|24|ft|m}} long. Sea kayaks can range in width from {{convert|20| to|24|in|mm}} ({{convert|57|-|76|cm|abbr=on|disp=or}}{{clarify|date=January 2015}}). Wider touring kayaks of {{convert|23|to|24|in|mm}} ({{convert|66|-|76|cm|abbr=on|disp=or}}{{clarify|date=January 2015}}) are better for bigger paddlers, or small/average sized paddlers looking for more initial stability and maneuverability. Narrower beams of {{convert|20|to|23|in|mm}} ({{convert|56|-|63.5|cm|abbr=on|disp=or}}{{clarify|date=January 2015}}) are good for small-medium-sized paddlers who want more speed and less maneuverability. And lastly, kayak depth (or the height from the hull to the highest area of the deck) can range from {{convert|11|to|13|in|mm}} ({{convert|33|-|40|cm|abbr=on|disp=or}}{{clarify|date=January 2015}}) high.
[[File:Explorer sea kayak side view.jpg|center]]
This design is typical of modern sea kayaks and has a low rear deck for easy rolling, a white water cockpit, compartments that allow the kayaker to reach into them while at sea, and a sloping rear bulkhead that enables the kayak to be emptied by lifting the bow.
==Safety== {{original research|section|date=August 2017}} [[File:St John Trunk Bay 5.jpg|right|thumb|Sea kayaking at [[Trunk Bay]] on [[Saint John, U.S. Virgin Islands|St. John]]]]
A sea kayak's primary safety device is its paddler. Although some kayakers consider a well-practised self-righting move such as an [[Eskimo roll]] to be essential in order to safe open-water kayaking, it is the technique of bracing that every well-trained, experienced kayaker practises in order to maintain an upright position in their kayak. Practice in bracing is often neglected by inexperienced kayakers once they have learned the Eskimo roll. However, the reality is that having to roll really means having to recover from a failed brace. Being in the capsized position in some environments due to missing a brace can put the paddler in danger of colliding with obstacles under the water. Staying upright in surf zones, rocky surf zones (informally known as rock gardens), and rivers is most important and is only accomplished through well-practised and successful bracing.
While there are a number of techniques for unassisted righting and re-entry of a kayak after a [[capsize]] and [[Turtling (sailing)|turtling]], most paddlers consider it safest to paddle with one or more others, as assistance is useful if attempting to recover via rolling solo fails. Even if the assistance fails to successfully right the kayaker, it is much easier to climb back into a boat in the open sea if one has another boat and paddler to help and the swamped boat has been emptied of water first. Nonetheless, experienced paddlers do attempt open-water crossings unaccompanied, and many major long-distance kayak expeditions have been carried out solo.
The use of a [[Paddle float]] self-rescue device, generally consisting of foam or in the form of an inflatable bag, and attached to the end of a paddle when needed, allows the paddle to be used as an outrigger while climbing back into the cockpit. If an inflatable paddle float is chosen, it should be a dual-chambered model on account of the safety advantage (in the event of failure of one chamber) that is conferred by the redundancy. The kayaker is advised to train with only one chamber inflated. In many areas (Canada, for instance), a paddle float is a safety item required by the coast guard. Re-entry using a paddle float is a fairly reliable rescue technique that, if well practised, allows one to paddle with confidence when one is not equipped with a flawlessly honed rolling skill.
There is a strong culture of self-sufficiency amongst sea kayakers and extensive safety equipment such as compass, towing lines, manual pumps, repair kits including wet application repair tape, flares, [[paddle leash]], spare paddles, and survival gear are routinely carried; along with supplies of food and a flask of hot beverage for non-emergency use. GPS, charts, lights, radios and cell phones, and [[radar reflector]]s are also sometimes carried.
==Forms of sea kayaking== [[File:Kayak Sailing on the Columbia.jpg|right|thumb|Kayak Sailing on the [[Columbia River]]]]
===Kayak Sailing=== Developed by kayak enthusiasts, Kayak sails can supplement or effectively eliminate the need for paddling. Using a sail can increase offshore range and allow longer expeditions. Use of a sail for touring has established a strong following with recreational sea kayakers, expedition paddlers, and adventure racers.
[[File:Sea Kayaking Wilsons Promontory.jpg|right|thumb|Sea Kayaking at Wilsons Promontory in Victoria, Australia]]
===Expedition Trips=== Weekend trips with overnight camping are popular among recreational kayakers and many combine kayaking with wildlife watching. Modern sea kayaks are designed to carry large amounts of equipment and unsupported expeditions of two weeks or more are conducted in environments ranging from the tropics to the Arctic. Expedition kayaks are designed to handle best when loaded, so it may be necessary to ballast them on shorter trips.
===Surf Kayaking=== {{details|Surf Kayaking}} {{details|Surf skis}} Closely related to surf boards and requiring a mix of [[surfing]] and kayaking skills, a wide range of sea kayaks are specifically designed for the sport of wave surfing.
===Sea Fishing=== {{main|Kayak fishing}}
The sea [[kayak]] has long been a means of transportation and a means of accessing fishing grounds and kayak fishing has gained popularity due to the availability of purpose built stable designs. This technological development also solves some ergonomic problems that are associated with sitting for long hours without being able to change positions and special kayaks for fishing are accessorized for this sport, including specially-designed hatches, built-in rod holders, catch bags and equipment mounts.
Many of the techniques used in kayak fishing are the same as those used on other fishing boats. The difference is in the set-up, how each piece of equipment is fitted to the kayak, and how each activity is carried out on such a small craft. Contemporary kayaks can be equipped with fishing aids such as rod holders, electronic [[Fishfinder|fish-finders]] and live-bait containers. Kayak [[Fisherman|anglers]] target highly prized bottom feeders like [[halibut]] and [[cod]] and also [[Pelagic zone|pelagics]] like [[amberjack]]s, [[tuna]], [[sailfish]], [[wahoo]], and even [[marlin]].
==Pioneering sea kayak expeditions== ;Pre-1900 * There is controversial evidence to suggest early trans-atlantic kayak journeys from Labrador or Greenland to Scotland by Inuit paddlers. Indeed, at the end of the 17th century there were at least three separate kayaks preserved in Scotland. One kayak, with associated equipment, is preserved in Aberdeen's [[Marischal Museum]]. It was found, with dying occupant, on a nearby shore. Some suggest the occupants were escaped Inuit from European ships, Inuit storm-driven from Greenland, or from a European source. Many suggest Inuit and their kayaks to be the origin of the Celtic [[Finn-men]], or [[Selkie]], legends.<ref>MacRitchie, Scot, ''The Aberdeen Kayak and its Congeners'', Royal Scottish Geographical Society Magazine, Feb 12, 1912, http://ads.ahds.ac.uk/catalogue/adsdata/PSAS_2002/pdf/vol_046/46_213_241.pdf</ref>
;1920s * [[Franz Romer]] crossed the Atlantic Ocean solo in a kayak in 1928. His crossing from the Canary Islands and toward Puerto Rico took 58 days at sea but he was lost in a hurricane trying to get to New York<ref>{{Cite news | last = Mahaffey | first = Dexter | title = The 10 All-time Greatest Sea Kayaking Expeditions | newspaper = Paddler Magazine | pages = | date = April 2003 | url = http://www.paddlermagazine.com/issues/2003_4/article_221.shtml | postscript = <!--None--> | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090518092243/http://www.paddlermagazine.com/issues/2003_4/article_221.shtml | archivedate = 2009-05-18 | df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vuQDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA586&dq=Popular+Mechanics+1931+curtiss&hl=en&ei=sZj0TNiVFcPXngeTp8W2CQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDMQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=Popular%20Mechanics%201931%20curtiss&f=true|title=Popular Mechanics|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Image:Speck-map.png|thumb|right|upright=1.2|Map of [[Oskar Speck]] journey (1932-1939) from Germany to Australia]] ;1930s * [[Oskar Speck]] paddled from Germany to Australia between 1932 and 1939.
;1950s * [[Hannes Lindemann]] sailed an Aerius II kayak from the Canary Islands to the Caribbean in 1956. Documented in the book "Alone at sea".<ref>{{cite book | last = Lindermann | first = Hannes | title = Alone at Sea A Doctor's Survival Experiments During Two Atlantic Crossings in a Dugout Canoe and a Folding Kayak | publisher = Pollner Verlag | year = 1998 | location = Germany | isbn = 3-925660-27-5}}</ref>
;1960s * Anne and Hamish Gow made the first kayak crossing from [[North Uist]] to [[St Kilda, Scotland]] in 1965. The Gows took film footage of the trip which was screened at the [[Edinburgh Mountain Film Festival]] in 2011.<ref>[http://simon-willis.blogspot.co.uk/2011/10/hamishs-kayaking-kilms-showing-at.html SimonWillis.net: Hamish's Kayaking Kilms Showing at Edinburgh Mtn Film Fest]. Simon-willis.blogspot.co.uk (2011-10-07). Retrieved on 2013-07-12.</ref>
;1970s * [[Derek Hutchinson]] was the first to cross the [[North sea]] in 1976. After several near-death failures he finally managed it in 31 hours.<ref>[http://www.paddlermagazine.com/issues/2003_4/article_221.shtml Paddler Magazine Online : The 10 All-time Greatest Sea Kayaking Expeditions<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090518092243/http://www.paddlermagazine.com/issues/2003_4/article_221.shtml |date=2009-05-18 }}</ref> The [http://www.nmmc.co.uk/index.php?/collections/featured_boats/baidarka_sea_kayak kayak] used in the crossing is today located in the [[National Maritime Museum Cornwall]]. * [[Nigel Foster (kayaker)|Nigel Foster]] and Geoff Hunter were the first to [[circumnavigate]] Iceland in 1977. * [[Frank Goodman (kayakist)|Frank Goodman]] was the first to circumnavigate Cape Horn in 1977. * [[Paul Caffyn]] was the first person to circumnavigate the [[South Island]] of [[New Zealand]] in the summer of 1977/78. He describes it in his book ''Obscured by Waves''. * [[Paul Caffyn]] was the first person to circumnavigate the [[North Island]] of [[New Zealand]] in the summer of 1978/79. He describes it in his book ''Cresting the Restless Waves''. * Earle Bloomfield and John Brewster first to circumnavigate [[Tasmania]], 1979
;1980s * [[Paul Caffyn]] and [[Nigel Dennis (kayakist)|Nigel Dennis]] were the first sea kayakers to circumnavigate Britain in 1980, a distance of {{convert|2200|mi|km}} in 85 days * [[Nigel Foster (kayaker)|Nigel Foster]] solo crossing of Hudson Strait from Baffin Island to Northern Labrador 1981 * [[Paul Caffyn]] was the first person to circumnavigate [[Australia]] in 1981/2 covering a distance of {{convert|9,420|mi|km}} He describes it in his book ''The Dreamtime Voyage''. * Laurie Ford solo across Bass Strait, (sail assisted) 1982. * David Taylor and James Moore were the first to circumnavigate [[The Faroe Islands]] (midway between Shetland and Iceland) in 1985. * Brian Wilson rounded Scotland's main coastline including the inner & outer Hebrideas on a solo trip over 4 months in 1985, described in his book 'Blazing Paddles'. * Earle Bloomfield, Larry Gray, Rob Casamento, and Graeme Joy northwards across Bass Strait (Note that the northward crossing is more difficult than the southward.) 1986. * [[Ed Gillet]] paddled from California to Hawaii in 1987. * [[Howard Rice]] first solo around [[Cape Horn]] in 1989.
;1990s * Adventurer [[Chris Duff]] circumnavigated both [[Ireland]] in 1996 and [[New Zealand]]'s [[South Island]] in 2000. * [[Trys Morris]] and Bob Timms have attempted to paddle from UK to Australia 1999 & 2000, abandoning the expedition in Athens, Greece due to lack of funds and visas for Arabian countries.
;2000s * Jon Turk and his team was the first to cross the [[Bering strait]] as they paddled from Japan to Alaska in 2000.<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/007147465X In the wake of the Jomon]</ref> * In his book ''Cold Oceans'' (1999), Jon Turk describes his attempt to solo circumnavigate [[Cape Horn]].<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/0613292103 Cold Oceans]</ref> * [[Peter Bray]] crossed from Canada to Ireland in 2001. * [[Trys Morris]], [[Gemma Rawlings]] and [[Justine Curgenven]] successfully circumnavigated [[Tasmania]] in 2004. This journey is featured in [[This Is The Sea 2]] * [[Fiona Whitehead]] circumnavigated Great Britain and Ireland in 2004 in 93 paddling days, 140 days in total. * In May 2004, Mark Western completed the first solo circumnavigation of Taiwan, total 34 days. * [[Harry Whelan]], [[Barry Shaw (kayaker)|Barry Shaw]] and [[Phil Clegg]] are considered to have been the fastest around Britain in 2005, completing the circumnavigation in 80 days * In November 2005 the first kayak circumnavigation of [[South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands|South Georgia]] in the Southern Atlantic was completed by The Adventure Philosophy team of Graham Charles, Marcus Waters and Mark Jones in 18 days, a distance of 600 km.<ref>[http://outside.away.com/outside/destinations/south-georgia-8.html November 2, 2005: South Georgia Expedition Update | Outside Online<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * [[Eric Stiller]] and Tony Brown unsuccessfully attempted circumnavigation of [[Australia]]. The trip ended in failure roughly a third of the way through. Described in the book ''Keep Australia on your left'' (2002). * Solo Kayak Circumnavigation of Iceland - Rotem Ron in the year (2006) [[Circumnavigation of Iceland]].<ref>[http://seakayak.co.il/eblog/?cat=1 טרה סנטה קיאקים ימיים]. Seakayak.co.il. Retrieved on 2013-07-12.</ref> * [[Andrew McAuley]], an Australian solo kayaker, was lost at sea in February 2007 only {{convert|30|nmi|km}} short of his destination of [[Milford Sound]], New Zealand, during his attempt to cross from Australia to New Zealand.<ref>{{cite news |title=Search for kayaker called off |url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/world/missing-kayakers-wife-losing-hope/2007/02/11/1171128816655.html?page=fullpage#contentSwap2 |date=12 February 2007 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> * Justin Jones and James Castrission made the first [[Crossing the Ditch|crossing]] from Australia to New Zealand, arriving on 13 January 2008, a journey that took 61 days. This is the longest two man kayak expedition ever undertaken.<ref>[http://www.crossingtheditch.com.au Home :: Crossing the Ditch - Trans-Tasman Kayak Expedition :: James Castrission & Justin Jones<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> * In 2009 there are 3 separate expeditions attempting to circumnavigate the [[Falkland Islands]]: two British teams<ref>[http://www.justgiving.com/kayakfalklands2009 Chris Millington is fundraising for Help for Heroes]. Justgiving.com. Retrieved on 2013-07-12.</ref> [[Tom Parrick]] and [[Fiona Whitehead]] <ref>[http://seakayakfalkland.blogspot.com Sea Kayak Falkland '09]. Seakayakfalkland.blogspot.com. Retrieved on 2013-07-12.</ref> and [[Marcus Demuth]], a solo American.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expeditionkayak.com/completed-expeditions/falkland-islands|title=Expeditionkayak.com Worldwide Kayak Expeditions, Sean Morley’s Kayak Expeditions Website, Publish your Kayak Expedition here, Kayalking in California, Sea Kayaking, Surf Kayaking, Paddlesports, California Paddlesports - Expeditionkayak.com|publisher=}}</ref> * In July 2009, Patrick Winterton and Mick Berwick completed the first unsupported kayak crossing from Scotland to the Faroe Islands.<ref>{{cite web|last=Flatman|first=Elizabeth|title=Kayakers complete first successful crossing to Faroes in aid of RNLI|url=http://www.rnli.org.uk/who_we_are/press_centre/news_releases/news_release_detail?articleid=461169|publisher=RNLI|accessdate=11 May 2012}}</ref> * [[Freya Hoffmeister]] made the "[[Race Around Australia]]" and successfully circumnavigated Australia at 2009. ;2010s * Fastest solo circumnavigation of Great Britain in 72 days by [http://performanceseakayak.co.uk/Pages/Records/UKCirc/recordsUKCirc.html John Willacy] and 67 days by [http://www.performanceseakayak.co.uk/Pages/Records/UKCirc/recordsUKCirc.php Joe Leach] (2012) * On the turn 2010/2011, Polish kayaker [[Aleksander Doba]] crossed from [[Dakar]] ([[Africa]] - [[Senegal]]) to [[Fortaleza]] ([[South America]] - [[Brasil]])<ref>[http://www.aleksanderdoba.pl Transatlantic kayak expedition]. Aleksanderdoba.pl. Retrieved on 2013-07-12.</ref> * On August 30, 2011, [[Freya Hoffmeister]] began a circumnavigation of South America. * In his lifetime, according to the [[Guinness Book of World Records]] [[Verlen Kruger]] paddled the most miles (over 100,000 miles) of anyone in the sport.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.canoekayak.com/canoe/krugerobit/ |title=Obituary: Verlen Kruger Remembered |author=canoekayakmag |date=August 9, 2004 |journal=Canoe & Kayak |accessdate=June 25, 2014}}</ref>
==See also== {{commons category|Sea kayaks}} {{Wikivoyage|Sea kayaking}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Aleutian kayak]] * [[Folding kayak]] * [[Kayak]] * [[Recreational kayak]] * [[Surf Kayaking]] * [[Whitewater kayaking]] {{div col end}}

{{About|the outdoor game|the genus of moths|Varpa (moth)}} [[File:Varpa-811285 1920.jpg|thumb|Varpa, [[Stånga Games]], Gotland.]] [[File:Kalkstenar på stranden Gotland.jpg|thumb|Flat [[limestone]]s from Gotland's beaches, [[Tumble finishing|tumbled]] and rounded by the sea are the original varpa stones used in the game]] '''Varpa''' is an outdoor [[game]] that dates back to the [[Viking Age]] and survived in [[Gotland]]. It is similar to [[boules]] and horseshoes but is played with a flat and heavy object called a "varpa" instead of balls. Varpas used to be well-shaped stones, but nowadays, aluminium is more popular. A varpa can weigh between a half kilo and five kilos. The object of the game is to throw the varpa as close to a stick as possible. The stick is 15 meters away for women and 20 meters away for men. The game can be played individually or in teams.
No official nationally sponsored varpa teams exist; however, unofficial leagues are growing in popularity among youth in suburban areas of Sweden and Norway.<ref name=spel>{{cite web|last1=Molin|first1=Maria|title=Stångaspelen för den oinvigde|trans-title=Stånga Games for the uninitiated|date=12 June 2015|url=http://www.gotland.net/se-och-gora/arkiv/stangaspelen-for-den-oinvigde/11142011|website=www.gotland.net|publisher=Gotlands Media AB|accessdate=24 June 2016}}</ref>
"Varpa" is an old word which simply means "to throw".
Varpa is one of the disciplines at the annual [[Stånga Games]] (''Stångaspelen'').<ref name="spel" />
== See also == * [[Caber toss]] * [[Game of physical skill]] * [[Pärk]]
== References == {{reflist}}

{{sport-stub}}

{{Infobox esl club | clubname = Wairarapa | image = [[File:WairarapaRugbyLogo.png|100px]] | fullname = ''Wairarapa Rugby Football Union'' | emblem = | colours = | founded = 1886 | sport = [[Rugby union]] | league = | ground = [[Memorial Park (Masterton)|Memorial Park]] |web = }} The '''Wairarapa Rugby Football Union''' was formed in 1886 and played until 1971, when they amalgamated with the [[Bush Rugby Football Union]] to form [[Wairarapa Bush Rugby Football Union]].
==All Blacks== Wairarapa had 15 All Blacks between 1903-1971.
==Ranfurly Shield== Wairarapa held the Ranfurly Shield, briefly in 1927, and again between 1928-29. They held it again for one match in 1950 before losing it to South Canterbury.
==References== * ''NZ Rugby Almanack'' * ''The Shield'' by Lindsay Knight

{{refimprove|date=September 2016}}
[[Image:Wicket-Keeping Gloves.jpg|thumb|A pair of wicket-keeping gloves. The webbing which helps the keeper to catch the ball can be seen between the thumb and index fingers.]] A '''wicket-keeper's gloves''' or '''mitt''' are large [[leather glove]]s worn by [[cricket]] players of the defending team which assist players in catching and fielding balls hit by a [[Batting (cricket)|batsman]] or thrown by a teammate.
==Legal specifications==
[[File:Wicket keeping gloves along with the inner gloves.jpg|thumb|right|Wicket keeping gloves along with the inner gloves]]
Law 40.2, which deals with the specifications for wicketkeepers' gloves, states that: If,.... the wicket-keeper wears gloves, they shall have no webbing between the fingers except joining index finger and thumb, where webbing may be inserted as a means of support. If used, the webbing shall be:
(a) a single piece of non-stretch material which, although it may have facing material attached, shall have no reinforcements or tucks.
(b) such that the top edge of the webbing-
(i) does not protrude beyond the straight line joining the top of the index finger to the top of the thumb.
(ii) is taut when a hand wearing the glove has the thumb fully extended.<ref>http://www.lords.org/laws-and-spirit/laws-of-cricket/laws/law-40-the-wicket-keeper,66,AR.html</ref>
==Major glove manufacturers== *[[Gray-Nicolls]] *[[Kookaburra Sport]] *[[Slazenger]] *[[Steeden]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2012}} {{Infobox video game |image=RVL WiiFitPlus logo E3.jpg |caption= Logo |composer=Asuka Ohta |developer=[[Nintendo Entertainment Analysis and Development|Nintendo EAD Group No. 5]] |publisher=[[Nintendo]] |director=Hiroshi Matsunaga |producer=[[Tadashi Sugiyama]] |released={{vgrelease|JP|October 1, 2009<ref name="JP release">{{cite web|author=Spencer |title=Standalone Wii Fit Plus Sold At A Deep Discount |url=http://www.siliconera.com/2009/07/23/standalone-wii-fit-plus-sold-at-a-deep-discount/ |work=Siliconera |date=July 23, 2009|accessdate=September 1, 2009}}</ref>|NA|October 4, 2009<ref name="NA release">{{cite web|title=Nintendo Unveils ''Wii Fit Plus'' Launch Date and New Colors of Nintendo DSi, Wii Remote |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20090831006002/en |publisher=Nintendo of America |location=Las Vegas, Nevada |date=August 31, 2009 |quote=Nintendo today announced that the new ''Wii Fit Plus'' game will launch in North America on Oct. 4 |accessdate=September 1, 2009}}</ref>|AUS|October 15, 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vooks.net/story-18482-Wii-Fit-Plus-dated-priced-for-Australia.html |title=Wii Fit Plus dated, priced for Australia – Australian Nintendo News Source – Vooks – 3DS – Wii- DS |publisher=Vooks |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref>}}{{vgrelease|EU|October 30, 2009<ref name="EUPress">{{cite press release|title=Nintendo introduces new social entertainment experiences at E3 Expo |publisher=Nintendo of Europe |date=June 2, 2009 |url=http://nintendo.co.uk/NOE/en_GB/news/2009/nintendo_introduces_new_social_entertainment_experiences_at_e3_expo_13655.html |accessdate =June 3, 2009}}</ref>}} |series=''[[Wii (video game series)|Wii]]'' |engine=[[Wii Fit]] |genre=[[Exergaming]] |modes=[[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] |platforms=[[Wii]] }}
{{nihongo|'''''Wii Fit Plus'''''|Wiiフィットプラス|Wī Fitto Purasu}} is an [[exergaming]] [[video game]] developed and published by [[Nintendo]] for the [[Wii]] [[video game console|console]]. The game was released in Japan on October 1, 2009 and other regions in the same month. ''Wii Fit Plus'' was announced during Nintendo's [[History of E3|E3 2009]] media briefing on June 2, 2009.
The game is an [[Video game remake|enhanced version]] of ''[[Wii Fit]]''.<ref name="NA release"/> In addition to the original ''Wii Fit'' activities and options, ''Wii Fit Plus'' incorporates 15 new balance and aerobics games (referred to as "Training Plus") and six new [[strength training]] and [[yoga]] activities.<ref name="EUPress"/> New features include a [[Food energy|calorie]] burning counter, the ability for users to create custom fitness regimens or choose from a number of specialized routines based on specific objectives and available time, as well as having the option to create profiles for pets and babies. Users are also able to navigate more quickly between exercises.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/gaming/2009-06-02-nintendo-wii-3e_N.htm | work=USA Today | title=Nintendo unveils sensor, 'Wii Fit Plus' at E3 video game expo | first=Mike | last=Snider | date=June 4, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gametrailers.com/game/wii-fit-plus/11418 |title=Wii Fit Plus Video Game | Reviews, Trailers & Interviews |publisher=GameTrailers.com |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.com.au/index.php?action=catalogue&prodcat_id=&prod_id=19238&pageID=2 |title=Wii Games – Wii Fit Plus |publisher=Nintendo.com.au |date=October 15, 2009 |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref>
''Wii Fit Plus'' is sold bundled with a [[Wii Balance Board]], as well as separately for existing Wii Balance Board owners.<ref name="EUPress" /> Most activities are for a single player, but there are a number of multi-player activities that allow for up to 8 players to take turns using one Wii Balance Board.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiifit.com/what-is-wii-fit-plus/multiplayer.html#multiplayer |title=What is Wii Fit Plus? |publisher=Wiifit.com |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref>
''Wii Fit Plus'' garnered both critical and commercial success. The game has received aggregate review scores of 80.83% and 80% on [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] respectively.<ref name="gr"/><ref name="mc"/> ''Wii Fit Plus'' is the seventh [[List of best-selling Wii video games|best-selling game on the Wii]], with a total of 21.13 million copies sold as of September 2018.<ref name="total sales"/>
==Gameplay== {{main|Wii Fit#Gameplay |l1=Wii Fit Gameplay}}
''Wii Fit Plus'' provides all of the original activities in ''[[Wii Fit]]'' in addition to fifteen Balance/Aerobics games (in a separate category called "Training Plus") and six [[Yoga]] and Strength-Training exercises unique to the game.
*'''[[Yoga]]''' **Spine Extension **Gate **Grounded V *'''[[Strength Training]]''' **Balance Bridge **Single-Leg Reach **Side Lunge *'''Training Plus''' Games marked with an asterisk (*) are remakes of games from the original ''Wii Fit''. **Perfect 10 **Island Cycling **Rhythm [[Chinese martial arts|Kung-Fu]] **[[Driving range|Driving Range]] **[[Segway PT|Segway]] Circuit **Bird's-Eye [[Bullseye (target)|Bulls-Eye]] **[[Snowball fight|Snowball Fight]] **[[Obstacle course|Obstacle Course]] **Tilt City **[[Marching band|Rhythm Parade]] **[[Rolling globe|Big Top]] [[Juggling]] **[[Skateboard]] [[Skatepark|Arena]] **Table Tilt Plus* **Balance Bubble Plus* **Basic Run Plus*
==Development== Producer [[Shigeru Miyamoto]] was inspired by the commercial success of ''[[Wii Fit]]'' to produce a follow-up. Miyamoto learned during ''Wii Fit Plus'' development that many ''Wii Fit'' owners had stopped playing the game, believing the primary reason to be inconvenience. A new menu interface, My Wii Fit Plus, was implemented to address this issue and make accessing activities quicker and easier. The interface was recreated and adjusted multiple times during development. In designing new minigames for ''Wii Fit Plus'', Miyamoto desired to create activities that played upon the [[Stroop effect]], requiring coordination of both the player's mind and body; minigames in which the player uses both the [[Wii Remote]] and the [[Wii Balance Board]] at the same time became a major focus.<ref name="iwata asks 1.1">{{cite web |url=https://www.nintendo.co.uk/Iwata-asks/Iwata-Asks-Wii-Fit-Plus/Interview-with-Shigeru-Miyamoto/1-Not-a-Sequel-but-an-Enhanced-Version/1-Not-a-Sequel-but-an-Enhanced-Version-209472.html |publisher=Nintendo of Europe |accessdate=December 12, 2012 |work=Iwata Asks: Wii Fit Plus |title=Not a Sequel but an Enhanced Version}}</ref>
==Reception== {{Video game reviews |GR=80.83%<ref name="gr">{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/wii/960488-wii-fit-plus/index.html |title=Wii Fit Plus Reviews |accessdate=December 11, 2012 |publisher=[[GameRankings]]}}</ref> |MC=80%<ref name="mc">{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/wii-fit-plus |title=Wii Fit Plus Reviews |accessdate=December 11, 2012 |publisher=[[Metacritic]]}}</ref> |1UP=A-<ref name="1up review">{{cite web|last=Barnholt |first=Ray |url=http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3176343&p=44 |title=Wii Fit Plus Review for Wii from |publisher=1UP.com |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref> |GSpot=7.5/10<ref name="gspot review">{{cite web|last=Ramsay |first=Randolph |url=http://www.gamespot.com/wii/sports/wiifitplus/review.html?tag=topslot;img;4 |title=Wii Fit Plus Review, Wii Fit Plus Wii Review |publisher=GameSpot.com |date=October 4, 2009 |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref> |IGN=8.2/10<ref name="ign review">{{cite web|author= Matt Casamassina |url=http://wii.ign.com/articles/103/1031024p1.html |title=Wii Fit Plus Review – Wii Review at IGN |publisher=Wii.ign.com |date=October 2, 2009 |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref> |NWR=9/10<ref name="nwr review">{{cite web |url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/review/20169 |title=Wii Fit Plus Review |author=Balicki, Lukasz |publisher=Nintendo World Report |date=October 18, 2009 |accessdate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> }}
''Wii Fit Plus'' generally received positive reviews from critics. [[GameRankings]] reports an aggregate score of 80.83% based on 18 reviews, and [[Metacritic]] reports a score of 80% based on 33 reviews. [[IGN]] gave ''Wii Fit Plus'' a score of 8.2.<ref name="ign review"/> [[GameSpot]] gave it a 7.5 out of 10.<ref name="gspot review"/> [[1up.com|1UP]] gave it an A-, stating, "There's still some tightening up to be done, but Wii Fit Plus is a definite improvement in the format."<ref name="1up review"/>
Within one month of its release, ''Wii Fit Plus'' sold 2.16 million copies worldwide,<ref name="initial sales">{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/pdf/2009/091030e.pdf#page=6|title= Financial Results Briefing for the Six-Month Period ended September 2009|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date =October 31, 2009|format=PDF| accessdate=October 30, 2009|page=11}}</ref> and as of September 2018, the game has sold 21.13 million units worldwide.<ref name="total sales">{{cite web|url=https://www.nintendo.co.jp/ir/en/sales/software/wii.html|title=Top Selling Software Sales Units - Wii Software|publisher=[[Nintendo]]|date=2016-03-31|accessdate=2016-04-27}}</ref>
In May 2010 the [[American Heart Association]] (AHA) endorsed the Wii to encourage sedentary people to take the first step toward fitness. The AHA heart icon covers the console itself along with two of its more active games, ''Wii Fit Plus'' and ''[[Wii Sports Resort]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/top-stories/ci_15104216 |title=Heart group backs Wii video game console in obesity campaign |author=Joel Schectman |agency=. Associated Press |date=May 17, 2010 |newspaper=San Jose Mercury News |accessdate=May 17, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.activeplaynow.com/ |title=American Heart Association and Nintendo of America Online Information Center |publisher=Activeplaynow.com |accessdate=September 28, 2011}}</ref>
